{"uri": "8094707979", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "10:39:23", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T10:39:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T10:38:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/law-order/2906061-russia-detains-ally-of-defence-minister-shoigu-for-alleged-corruption", "title": "Russia detains ally of Defence Minister Shoigu for alleged corruption | Law-Order", "body": "Some Russian bloggers, who have accused senior generals of incompetence, rejoiced at the apparent fall of a top military official long linked to the ostentatious opulence which Putin has made clear he does not want to see displayed in wartime. A Russian source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Ivanov was a close ally of Shoigu and that his arrest was a sharp blow for the defence minister.\n\nA Russian court on Wednesday ordered one of Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu's deputies be kept in custody on suspicion of taking bribes, the highest-profile corruption case since President Vladimir Putin sent troops into Ukraine in 2022. Deputy Defence Minister Timur Ivanov was detained on Tuesday at work by the Federal Security Service (FSB), the main successor to the Soviet-era KGB, for accepting large bribes.\n\nMoscow's Basmanny District Court ordered Ivanov be kept in custody until June 23. Ivanov, 48, was shown in uniform standing in a glass cage in court, frowning slightly, footage released by the court service showed. \"The investigation believes that Ivanov entered into a criminal conspiracy with third parties, teamed up with them in advance to commit an organised crime by an organised group,\" the court service said.\n\nIt said the conspiracy was to receive \"property and services on a particularly large scale during contract and sub-contract work for the ministry of defence.\" Ivanov, who said he was innocent, faces 15 years in jail if convicted. State media gave the case full coverage.\n\nThe sudden arrest of an ally of Shoigu, who Putin tasked with fighting the war in Ukraine, triggered speculation about a battle within the elite and of a public crackdown on the corruption that has plagued Russia's post-Soviet armed forces. Some Russian bloggers, who have accused senior generals of incompetence, rejoiced at the apparent fall of a top military official long linked to the ostentatious opulence which Putin has made clear he does not want to see displayed in wartime.\n\nA Russian source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Ivanov was a close ally of Shoigu and that his arrest was a sharp blow for the defence minister. Shoigu, a Putin ally and one of Russia's most powerful men, is widely expected to keep his position in a coming government reshuffle. The Kremlin said Putin and Shoigu had been informed. The defence ministry made no comment. A close friend of Ivanov, Sergei Borodin, was also charged with conspiring to take bribes.\n\nOSTENTATIOUS WEALTH Ivanov, who has served as deputy minister since 2016, was in charge of property management, housing, construction and mortgages at the defence ministry, whose spending has spiralled since the war began.\n\nThe TASS state news agency said the investigation into Ivanov has been under way for some time and that the FSB's military counter-intelligence department was involved. The Kremlin dismissed a Russian report that Ivanov may be suspected of treason as pure speculation.\n\nIvanov had long been the subject of journalistic investigations. Russia's Anti-Corruption Foundation, headed by the late Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny, had alleged that Ivanov and his family lived a life of luxury including yachts, helicopters, visits to the French Riviera, purchases of diamonds and a 19th Century mansion in Moscow. Forbes magazine listed Ivanov as one of the wealthiest men in Russia's security structures. Other investigations alleged corruption in Russia's reconstruction of the Ukrainian city of Mariupol now controlled by Russian forces.\n\nIvanov was unable to comment as he was in detention. Putin last month ordered the FSB to root out corruption in state defence procurement. Ivanov, who graduated with from Moscow State University with a mathematics degree, rose through the ranks of Russia's state atomic energy sector before becoming deputy head of the Moscow region government under Shoigu, who was then governor.\n\nSome Russian military bloggers have long accused top generals of corruption, especially after the army's hurried withdrawal from parts of Ukraine after over-extending itself during the first days of the invasion. \"It is clear that this is a tectonic shift,\" said Yuri Podolyaka, a popular pro-Russian military blogger. \"And this is not about Ivanov... I hope this is only the beginning.\"\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8094465123", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "08:15:32", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T08:15:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T08:15:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.news24.com/news24/world/news/russia-detains-deputy-of-defence-minister-sergei-shoigu-for-large-scale-corruption-20240424", "title": "Russia detains deputy of defence minister Sergei Shoigu for 'large scale' corruption | News24", "body": "There was no immediate official confirmation of others who were reportedly arrested alongside him.\n\nRussian security services detained one of Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu's deputies on suspicion of taking major bribes, the highest-profile corruption case since President Vladimir Putin sent troops into Ukraine in February 2022.\n\nDeputy Defence Minister Timur Ivanov was detained on Tuesday, according to a brief 22-word statement by Russia's investigative committee. The statute that the investigators cited for his detention is for accepting bribes \"on a particularly large scale\".\n\nHe faces 15 years in jail if convicted.\n\nThe sudden arrest of an ally of Shoigu, who Putin tasked with fighting the war in Ukraine, triggered speculation about a battle within the elite and of a public crackdown on the corruption which has plagued Russia's post-Soviet armed forces.\n\nThe Kremlin said Putin had been informed, and added that Shoigu had also been told. Ivanov was present earlier on Tuesday at a meeting of top defence officials chaired by Shoigu.\n\nIvanov, who has served as deputy minister since 2016, was in charge of property management, housing, construction and mortgages at the defence ministry. The defence ministry has made no comment.\n\nRussia's Kommersant newspaper said that Ivanov, 48, was arrested by the Federal Security Service (FSB), the successor to the Soviet-era KGB which Putin last month told to root out corruption in state defence procurement.\n\nThe Izvestia newspaper said others had also been detained, though there was no official confirmation of that. The newspaper said Ivanov's properties were being searched. State television gave the case full coverage.\n\n\"Lets just say the investigation did not start yesterday, the day before yesterday or even a month ago,\" an unidentified Russia law enforcement source told the TASS state news agency. FSB military counter-intelligence was involved, TASS said.\n\nIt was not immediately clear why such a senior official with a close association with Shoigu would be targeted.\n\nRussian military bloggers have long accused top generals of corruption and incompetence, especially after the army's hurried withdrawal from parts of Ukraine after seriously over-extending itself during the first days of the invasion.\n\nWithin the Russian elite, there are a range of views on the war, which has had touched off the worst breakdown in relations between Russia and the West since the 1962 Cuban Missile Crisis.\n\nIvanov, who could not be reached as he was in detention, has long been linked to the ostentatious opulence which has characterised some sections of the post-Soviet Russian elite, including luxurious real estate and flashy parties.\n\nIn 2022, Russia's Anti-Corruption Foundation, headed by the late Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny, alleged that Ivanov and his family led a lavish lifestyle.\n\nIvanov, who was born in Moscow, graduated with a degree in mathematics from Moscow State University and completed a dissertation in the organisational models for the construction of nuclear power plants.\n\nHe rose through the ranks of Russia's state atomic energy sector and worked as an adviser to the energy minister before moving to become the deputy head of Moscow region's government under Shoigu, who was then governor.\n\nFrom 2013, Ivanov headed a defence ministry construction company which builds housing for soldiers and at high-security installations.\n\nForbes {"uri": "2024-04-334418639", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "21:18:46", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T21:18:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T15:28:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://arab.news/rwfy4", "title": "A Russian deputy defense minister is ordered jailed pending trial on", "body": "The committee gave no further information, apart from saying Ivanov is suspected of taking an especially large bribe -- an offense punishable by up to 15 years in prison\n\nMOSCOW: A Russian deputy defense minister in charge of military construction projects and accused of living a lavish lifestyle was ordered jailed Wednesday pending an investigation and trial on charges of bribery, court officials said in a statement.\n\nTimur Ivanov, one of 12 deputy defense ministers, appeared in Moscow's Basmany court Wednesday wearing his military uniform. The ally of Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu was arrested Tuesday evening, Russia's Investigative Committee said in a statement.\n\nThe committee gave no further information, apart from saying Ivanov is suspected of taking an especially large bribe -- an offense punishable by up to 15 years in prison.\n\nThe Kremlin rejected some Russian media reports that Ivanov was suspected of treason.\n\nIvanov, 48, was sanctioned by both the United States and European Union in 2022 after Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine.\n\nAccording to a court statement, investigators told the judge that Ivanov had conspired with third parties to receive a bribe in the form of unspecified property services \"during contracting and subcontracting work for the needs of the Ministry of Defense.\"\n\nAn acquaintance of Ivanov's, identified as Sergei Borodin, also was arrested and ordered jailed pending an investigation and trial on the same charges, court officials said. Both men are to remain in custody until at least June 23.\n\nAccording to the Defense Ministry's website, Ivanov was appointed in 2016 by a presidential decree. He oversaw property management, housing and medical support for the military, as well as construction projects.\n\nRussia's state news agency RIA Novosti quoted Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov as saying that Shoigu and President Vladimir Putin were informed of Ivanov's arrest, which comes as Moscow's war in Ukraine grinds through its third year.\n\nPeskov dismissed Russian media reports that the corruption allegations against Ivanov were intended to obscure additional allegations of high treason.\n\nIndependent Russian news outlet reported that the bribery charges were intended to hide more serious charges of treason and avoid scandal, citing two unidentified sources close to the Federal Security Service, or FSB.\n\nPeskov described the reports as speculation. \"There are a lot of rumors. We need to rely on official information,\" he told journalists.\n\nIvanov's lawyer also denied any other charges, telling RIA Novosti that he faced only bribery allegations.\n\nBefore his arrest, Ivanov was seen attending a meeting with Shoigu and other military brass.\n\nRussian media reported that he oversaw some of the construction in Mariupol -- a Ukrainian port city that was devastated by bombardment and occupied by Russian forces early in the war.\n\nZvezda, the official TV channel of the Russian military, reported in summer 2022 that the ministry was building an entire residential block in Mariupol and showed Ivanov inspecting construction sites and newly erected residential buildings.\n\nThat same year, the team of the late Alexei Navalny, Russia's most prominent opposition leader and anti-corruption campaigner, alleged Ivanov and his family had been enjoying luxurious trips abroad, lavish parties and owning elite real estate. The activists also alleged that Ivanov's wife, Svetlana, divorced him in 2022 to avoid sanctions and continued living a lavish lifestyle.\n\nCommenting on Ivanov's case, Navalny's ally Maria Pevchikh said on social platform X: \"It's a good day today.\"\n\nThe prosecution of high-level officials for corruption remains relatively rare in Russia.\n\nThe most recent arrest in April 2023 saw former Deputy Culture Minister Olga Yarilova charged with embezzling more than 200 million rubles ($2.2 million). Yarilova, who held her post between 2018 and 2022, is on trial and facing a seven-year jail term.\n\nFormer Economics Minister Alexei Ulyukayev received an eight-year prison sentence in 2017 for accepting a $2 million bribe from one of Putin's top associates. The high-profile trial was widely seen as part of infighting between Kremlin clans. Ulyukayev, now 68, was granted early release from prison in May 2022.", "source": {"uri": "arab.news", "dataType": "news", "title": "Arab News"}, "authors": [{"uri": "associated_press@arab.news", {"uri": "8094699817", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "10:34:13", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T10:34:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T10:33:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8039215803146362, "url": "https://www.euronews.com/2024/04/24/a-russian-deputy-defence-minister-appears-in-court-on-bribery-charges", "title": "A Russian deputy defence minister appears in court on bribery charges", "body": "Timur Ivanov is accused of accepting a massive bribe when he was one of Russia's 12 deputy defence ministers.\n\nIvanov, who was arrested on Tuesday, appeared in court in central Moscow on Wednesday morning, Russia's Investigative Committee said in a statement.\n\nIt gave no further information, apart from specifying that Ivanov is suspected of taking an especially large bribe - a criminal offence punishable by up to 15 years in prison.\n\nHe will remain in pre-trial custody.\n\nAccording to a statement from the court, investigators told Moscow's Basmany court on Wednesday that Ivanov had conspired with third parties to receive a bribe in the form of unspecified property services \"during contracting and subcontracting work for the needs of the Ministry of Defence.\"\n\nAn acquaintance of Ivanov's, identified as Sergei Borodin, was also arrested and ordered into pre-trial detention on the same charges, court officials said in a separate statement. Both men are to remain in custody until at least June 23.\n\nAccording to the defence ministry's website, Ivanov was appointed to the post in 2016 by a presidential decree. He oversaw property management, housing and medical support for the military, construction and reconstruction of facilities.\n\nRussia's state news agency RIA Novosti quoted Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov as saying that both President Vladimir Putin and Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu were informed about Ivanov's arrest, which comes as Moscow's war in Ukraine continues into its third year.\n\nBefore his arrest on Tuesday evening, Ivanov was seen attending a meeting with Shoigu and other top military brass.\n\nRussian media reported that he was in charge, among other things, of some of the construction in Mariupol, a port city in Ukraine's partially occupied Donestk region which was heavily bombarded and occupied by Russian forces early on in the war in 2022.\n\nZvezda, the official TV channel of the Russian military, reported in the summer of 2022 that the ministry \"is building an entire residential block\" in the severely damaged city and showed Ivanov inspecting construction sites.\n\nThat same year, the team of the late Alexei Navalny, Russia's most prominent opposition leader and anti-corruption campaigner, alleged that Ivanov and his family had been living an extravagant life with luxurious trips abroad, lavish parties and elite real estate. The opposition activists also alleged that Ivanov's wife Svetlana divorced him in the summer of 2022, avoided sanctions and continued to enjoy the lavish lifestyle.\n\nCommenting on the detention of Ivanov on Tuesday, Navalny's ally Maria Pevchikh wrote on X, formerly Twitter: \"It's a good day today.\"\n\nTransparency International, an anti-corruption pressure group, ranked Russia 141st out of 180 countries in its Corruption Perceptions Index, alongside Guinea, Kyrgyzstan and Uganda. {"uri": "8094164292", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "04:35:45", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T04:35:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T04:35:11Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/politics/2905692-russian-deputy-defence-minister-detained-on-bribe-allegations-officials-say", "title": "Russian deputy defence minister detained on bribe allegations, officials say | Politics", "body": "A Russian deputy defence minister in charge of military construction has been detained on Tuesday on suspicion of \"large-scale\" bribe-taking, in one of the highest-profile corruption cases since Moscow launched its war in Ukraine. A brief statement by the Investigative Committee, Russia's top investigative body, said late on Tuesday that Timur Ivanov had been taken into custody and an investigation into his case was proceeding.\n\nA Russian deputy defence minister in charge of military construction has been detained on Tuesday on suspicion of \"large-scale\" bribe-taking, in one of the highest-profile corruption cases since Moscow launched its war in Ukraine.\n\nA brief statement by the Investigative Committee, Russia's top investigative body, said late on Tuesday that Timur Ivanov had been taken into custody and an investigation into his case was proceeding. The statute that the investigators cited for the detention of Ivanov, who has been in his job for eight years, is for accepting bribes \"on a particularly large scale\".\n\nIn 2022, Russia's Anti-Corruption Foundation, headed by the late Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny, alleged that Ivanov and his family led a lavish lifestyle filled with spending on real estate, luxurious trips and designer clothing. Russian media reported that Ivanov was in charge, among other things, of large construction projects rebuilding the eastern Ukrainian city of Mariupol, which was heavily bombarded and taken by Russia as part of Moscow's invasion of Ukraine.\n\nKremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov, quoted by Russian news agencies, said a report on Ivanov's detention had been presented to President Vladimir Putin. Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu had been informed in advance of his detention, he said. The daily Izvestia reported on Wednesday, citing sources, that searches were conducted late on Tuesday at some of Ivanov's properties.\n\nRussian news reports said that Ivanov, if convicted, could face up to 15 years in prison. Forbes magazine listed Ivanov, an expert in cybernetics and the nuclear industry, as one of the wealthiest men in Russia's security structures.\n\nNews outlet RBK posted a picture of him attending a meeting of ministerial officials earlier on Tuesday chaired by Shoigu. Russian news reports said Ivanov was likely the most senior Russian official to face such charges since Moscow launched its invasion of Ukraine in February 2022.\n\nHe worked in companies dealing with fuel and energy and in the Moscow regional government before joining the defence ministry in 2010. He became a deputy minister in 2016.\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "2024-04-335569050", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "18:30:18", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T18:30:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T17:38:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.800000011920929, "url": "https://www.republicworld.com/world-news/russia/russia-third-man-held-in-bribery-case-involving-deputy-defence-minister", "title": "Russia: Third Man Held in Bribery Case Involving Deputy Defence Minister", "body": "Russian Deputy Defence Minister Timur Ivanov was arrested earlier this week on suspicion of accepting a bribe. | Image:AP\n\nMoscow: A third man has been detained in a bribery case involving one of Russia's most senior defense officials, Moscow's court service said Thursday. It said businessman Alexander Fomin is suspected of paying bribes to Deputy Defence Minister Timur Ivanov, who was detained on Wednesday, as well as Ivanov's associate, Sergei Borodin. All of the men are to remain in custody until at least June 23.\n\nA 'particularly large bribe'\n\nIt is rare for such a high-ranking official to be accused of a crime in Russia. Ivanov, an ally of Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu, was jailed pending an investigation and trial on charges of bribery, court officials said in a statement.\n\nHe was in charge of military construction projects and was previously accused of living a lavish lifestyle in anti-corruption investigations conducted by the team of late Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny. It is unclear what sparked the decision to charge him with bribery.\n\nIvanov, 48, was sanctioned by both the United States and European Union in 2022 after Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine. President Putin's spokesperson, Dmitry Peskov, said Wednesday that the construction projects that were overseen by Ivanov will continue.\n\nMoscow's court service said Fomin and Borodin contributed to Ivanov receiving a \"particularly large bribe\" -- an offense punishable by up to 15 years in prison. As part of the case against Fomin and the deputy minister, the courts service added that Fomin did not pay for goods, work and services related to repairing and reconstructing buildings.\n\nRussian state news agency Tass reported Wednesday that a Moscow businessman whose company is involved in construction gave testimony which incriminated the deputy defence minister. Tass did not name the individual who gave the evidence, but public records and Russian newspapers say that Alexander Fomin owns half of the company, called Olimpsitistroy.\n\nIn 2021, Ivanov awarded Fomin and the co-owner of Olimpsitistroy a state award called For Merit to the Fatherland for building medical centers, the Russian newspaper Kommersant reported.\n\nAccording to a court statement Wednesday, investigators told the judge that Ivanov conspired with third parties to receive a bribe in the form of unspecified property services \"during contracting and subcontracting work for the needs of the Ministry of Defense.\"\n\nIvanov's lawyer, Murad Musayev, told the state news agency Tass on Wednesday that his client is accused of \"taking a bribe in the form of free construction and repair work on supposedly his personal properties,\" and in turn providing \"assistance to companies that were contractors for the Defence Ministry.\"\n\nAnother lawyer, Denis Baluyev, was quoted by state news agency RIA Novosti as saying Wednesday that Ivanov maintains his innocence.\n\nAllegations of other hidden charges\n\nAccording to the Defence Ministry's website, Ivanov was appointed in 2016 by a presidential decree. He oversaw property management, housing and medical support for the military, as well as construction projects.\n\nRIA Novosti quoted Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov as saying that Shoigu and President Vladimir Putin were informed of Ivanov's arrest, which comes as Moscow's war in Ukraine grinds through its third year.\n\nIndependent Russian news outlets reported Wednesday that the bribery charges were intended to hide more serious charges of treason and avoid scandal, citing two unidentified sources close to the Federal Security Service, or FSB.\n\nPeskov dismissed the suggestion and described the reports as speculation. \"There are a lot of rumors. We need to rely on official information,\" he told journalists.\n\nMusayev, Ivanov's lawyer, also denied any other charges, telling RIA Novosti Ivanov faced only bribery allegations.\n\nBefore his arrest, Ivanov was seen attending a meeting with Shoigu and other top military brass. The move against Ivanov came nearly a month after Putin called on the FSB to \"keep up a systemic anti-corruption effort\" and pay special attention to state defense procurement.\n\nRussian media reported that Ivanov oversaw some of the construction in Mariupol, a Ukrainian port city that was devastated by bombardment and occupied by Russian forces early in the war.\n\nZvezda, the official TV channel of the Russian military, reported in summer 2022 that the ministry was building an entire residential block in Mariupol and showed Ivanov inspecting construction sites and newly erected buildings.\n\nThat same year, the team of opposition leader Navalny alleged Ivanov and his family had been enjoying luxurious trips abroad, lavish parties and owned elite real estate. The activists also alleged that Ivanov's wife, Svetlana, divorced him in 2022 to avoid sanctions and continued living a lavish lifestyle.\n\nRare prosecution\n\nFew high-level officials have been prosecuted in Russia.\n\nIn April 2023, former Deputy Culture Minister Olga Yarilova was arrested and charged with embezzling more than 200 million rubles ($2.2 million). Yarilova, who held her post from 2018 to 2022, is on trial and facing a possible seven-year jail term.\n\nFormer Economics Minister Alexei Ulyukayev received an eight-year prison sentence in 2017 for accepting a $2 million bribe from one of Putin's top associates. The high-profile trial was widely seen as part of infighting between Kremlin clans. Ulyukayev, now 68, was granted early release from prison in May 2022.", "source": {"uri": "republicworld.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Republic World"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8094960048", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "13:08:59", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T13:08:59Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T13:07:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.latestly.com/agency-news/world-news-top-russian-military-official-appears-in-court-on-bribery-charges-5917284.html", "title": "World News | Top Russian Military Official Appears in Court on Bribery Charges | LatestLY", "body": "Moscow, Apr 24 (AP) A top Russian military official arrested on suspicion of accepting a bribe was sent to pre-trial detention on Wednesday after appearing before a court in central Moscow, court officials said in a statement.\n\nTimur Ivanov, 48, one of Russia's 12 deputy defence ministers, was arrested Tuesday evening, Russia's Investigative Committee said in a statement. It gave no further information, apart from specifying that Ivanov is suspected of taking an especially large bribe -- a criminal offense punishable by up to 15 years in prison.\n\nAlso Read | Japan: Smoke Seen as ANA Flight Carrying About 200 People Lands Safely in Northern Japan, Public TV Says.\n\nAccording to a statement from the court, investigators told Moscow's Basmany court on Wednesday that Ivanov had conspired with third parties to receive a bribe in the form of unspecified property services \"during contracting and subcontracting work for the needs of the Ministry of Defence\".\n\nAn acquaintance of Ivanov's, identified as Sergei Borodin, was also arrested and ordered into pre-trial detention on the same charges, court officials said in a separate statement. Both men are to remain in custody until at least June 23.\n\nAlso Read | What is 'Love Brain'? All You Need to Know About the Disorder That Made a Chinese Girl Call Her Boyfriend 100 Times Daily.\n\nAccording to the defense ministry's website, Ivanov was appointed to the post in 2016 by a presidential decree. He oversaw property management, housing and medical support for the military, construction and reconstruction of facilities.\n\nRussia's state news agency RIA Novosti quoted Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov as saying that both President Vladimir Putin and Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu were informed about Ivanov's arrest, which comes as Moscow's war in Ukraine continues into its third year.\n\nPeskov also dismissed reports in the Russian media on Wednesday that the corruption allegations against Ivanov were intended to obscure additional allegations of high treason.\n\nIndependent Russian news outlet reported that the bribery charges were intended to hide more serious charges and avoid public scandal, citing two unnamed sources close to Russia's Federal Security Services.\n\nPeskov described the reports as speculation. \"There are a lot of rumors: we need to rely on official information,\" he told journalists.\n\nIvanov's lawyer also denied any additional charges, telling RIA Novosti that official was only facing bribery allegations.\n\nBefore his arrest on Tuesday evening, Ivanov was seen attending a meeting with Shoigu and other top military brass.\n\nRussian media reported that he was in charge, among other things, of some of the construction in Mariupol -- a port city in Ukraine's partially occupied Donestk region which was heavily bombarded and occupied by Russian forces early on in the war in 2022.\n\nZvezda, the official TV channel of the Russian military, reported in the summer of 2022 that the ministry \"is building an entire residential block\" in the severely damaged city and showed Ivanov inspecting construction sites.\n\nThat same year, the team of the late Alexei Navalny, Russia's most prominent opposition leader and anti-corruption campaigner, alleged that Ivanov and his family had been living an extravagant life with luxurious trips abroad, lavish parties and elite real estate. The opposition activists also alleged that Ivanov's wife Svetlana divorced him in the summer of 2022, avoided sanctions and continued to enjoy the lavish lifestyle.\n\nCommenting on the detention of Ivanov on Tuesday, Navalny's ally Maria Pevchikh said on X, formerly Twitter: \"It's a good day today.\" (AP)", "source": {"uri": "latestly.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "LatestLY"}, "authors": It also showed that the personal bills of Ivanov's wife were paid by a company engaged in the restoration of Mariupol.\n\nAccording to the FBK, which has been banned in Russia for alleged extremism, the minister divorced his wife to allow her to bypass EU sanctions.\n\n\"Today is a good day,\" said Maria Pevchikh, the head of investigations at the foundation, in a post on X, formerly Twitter.\n\n\"The person involved in our investigation was detained on suspicion of bribery. We talked about the glamorous and luxurious life of Deputy Defense Minister Timur Ivanov back at the end of 2022.\"\n\nIvanov was appointed deputy defense minister by presidential decree in May 2016.\n\nKremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said a report on Ivanov's detention had been presented to President Vladimir Putin, according to Russian news agencies.\n\nDefense Minister Sergei Shoigu had been informed in advance of his detention, he said.\n\nIvanov's duties included overseeing housing for troops and the construction and overhaul of ministry facilities. Ivanov has been designated for sanctions by United States, the European Union, Britain, and Canada.\n\nForbes magazine listed Ivanov as one of the wealthiest men in Russia's security structures.", {"uri": "8094175324", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "04:44:55", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T04:44:55Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T04:44:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.streetinsider.com/Reuters/Russian+deputy+defence+minister+detained+on+bribe+allegations%2C+officials+say/23105131.html", "title": "Russian deputy defence minister detained on bribe allegations, officials say", "body": "(Reuters) -A Russian deputy defence minister in charge of military construction has been detained on Tuesday on suspicion of \"large-scale\" bribe-taking, in one of the highest-profile corruption cases since Moscow launched its war in Ukraine.\n\nA brief statement by the Investigative Committee, Russia's top investigative body, said late on Tuesday that Timur Ivanov had been taken into custody and an investigation into his case was proceeding.\n\nThe statute that the investigators cited for the detention of Ivanov, who has been in his job for eight years, is for accepting bribes \"on a particularly large scale\".\n\nIn 2022, Russia's Anti-Corruption Foundation, headed by the late Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny, alleged that Ivanov and his family led a lavish lifestyle filled with spending on real estate, luxurious trips and designer clothing.\n\nRussian media reported that Ivanov was in charge, among other things, of large construction projects rebuilding the eastern Ukrainian city of Mariupol, which was heavily bombarded and taken by Russia as part of Moscow's invasion of Ukraine.\n\nKremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov, quoted by Russian news agencies, said a report on Ivanov's detention had been presented to President Vladimir Putin. Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu had been informed in advance of his detention, he said.\n\nThe daily Izvestia reported on Wednesday, citing sources, that searches were conducted late on Tuesday at some of Ivanov's properties.\n\nRussian news reports said that Ivanov, if convicted, could face up to 15 years in prison.\n\nForbes magazine listed Ivanov, an expert in cybernetics and the nuclear industry, as one of the wealthiest men in Russia's security structures.\n\nNews outlet RBK posted a picture of him attending a meeting of ministerial officials earlier on Tuesday chaired by Shoigu.\n\nRussian news reports said Ivanov was likely the most senior Russian official to face such charges since Moscow launched its invasion of Ukraine in February 2022.\n\nHe worked in companies dealing with fuel and energy and in the Moscow regional government before joining the defence ministry in 2010. He became a deputy minister in 2016.\n\n(Reporting by Reuters; Writing by Ron Popeski and Lidia Kelly; Editing by Daniel Wallis and Gerry Doyle)", "source": {"uri": "streetinsider.com", "dataType": {"uri": "8095348672", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "17:17:01", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T17:17:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T17:16:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.irishtimes.com/world/europe/2024/04/24/russia-detains-ally-of-defence-minister-shoigu-for-alleged-corruption/", "title": "Russia detains ally of defence minister Shoigu for alleged corruption", "body": "Deputy minister Timur Ivanov suspected of bribe-taking in Russia's highest-profile corruption case since Ukraine invasion\n\nA Russian court on Wednesday ordered that one of defence minister Sergei Shoigu's deputies be kept in custody on suspicion of taking bribes, the highest-profile corruption case since President Vladimir Putin sent troops into Ukraine in 2022.\n\nDeputy defence minister Timur Ivanov was detained on Tuesday at work by the Federal Security Service (FSB), the main successor to the Soviet-era KGB, for accepting large bribes.\n\nMoscow's Basmanny district court ordered that Mr Ivanov be kept in custody until June 23rd. Mr Ivanov (48) was shown in uniform standing in a glass cage in court, frowning slightly, footage released by the court service showed.\n\n\"The investigation believes that Ivanov entered into a criminal conspiracy with third parties, teamed up with them in advance to commit an organised crime by an organised group,\" the court service said.\n\nIt said the conspiracy was to receive \"property and services on a particularly large scale during contract and sub-contract work for the ministry of defence\".\n\nMr Ivanov, who said he was innocent, faces 15 years in jail if convicted. State media gave the case full coverage.\n\nThe sudden arrest of an ally of Mr Shoigu, who Mr Putin tasked with fighting the war in Ukraine, triggered speculation about a battle within the elite and of a public crackdown on the corruption that has plagued Russia's post-Soviet armed forces.\n\nSome Russian bloggers, who have accused senior generals of incompetence, rejoiced at the apparent fall of a top military official long linked to the ostentatious opulence that Mr Putin has made clear he does not want to see displayed in wartime.\n\nA Russian source, speaking on condition of anonymity, said Mr Ivanov was a close ally of Mr Shoigu and that his arrest was a sharp blow for the defence minister. Mr Shoigu, a Putin ally and one of Russia's most powerful men, is widely expected to keep his position in a coming government reshuffle.\n\nThe Kremlin said Mr Putin and Mr Shoigu had been informed. The defence ministry made no comment. A close friend of Mr Ivanov, Sergei Borodin, was also charged with conspiring to take bribes.\n\nMr Ivanov, who has served as deputy minister since 2016, was in charge of property management, housing, construction and mortgages at the defence ministry, whose spending has spiralled since the war began.\n\nThe Tass state news agency said the investigation into Mr Ivanov has been under way for some time and that the FSB's military counter-intelligence department was involved.\n\nThe Kremlin dismissed a Russian report that Mr Ivanov may be suspected of treason as pure speculation.\n\nMr Ivanov had long been the subject of journalistic investigations. Russia's Anti-Corruption Foundation, headed by the late Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny, had alleged that Mr Ivanov and his family lived a life of luxury including yachts, helicopters, visits to the French Riviera, purchases of diamonds and a 19th Century mansion in Moscow.\n\nForbes magazine listed Mr Ivanov as one of the wealthiest men in Russia's security structures. Other investigations alleged corruption in Russia's reconstruction of the Ukrainian city of Mariupol now controlled by Russian forces.\n\nMr Ivanov was unable to comment as he was in detention. Mr Putin last month ordered the FSB to root out corruption in state defence procurement.\n\nMr Ivanov, who graduated with from Moscow State University with a mathematics degree, rose through the ranks of Russia's state atomic energy sector before becoming deputy head of the Moscow region government under Mr Shoigu, who was then governor.\n\nSome Russian military bloggers have long accused top generals of corruption, especially after the army's hurried withdrawal from parts of Ukraine after over-extending itself during the first days of the invasion.\n\n\"It is clear that this is a tectonic shift,\" said Yuri Podolyaka, a popular pro-Russian military blogger. \"And this is not about Ivanov... {"uri": "8096349396", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "08:41:06", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T08:41:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T08:40:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.startribune.com/third-man-is-detained-in-a-major-bribery-case-that-involves-russias-deputy-defense-minister/600361509/", "title": "Third man is detained in a major bribery case that involves Russia's deputy defense minister", "body": "A third man has been detained in a bribery case involving a Russian deputy defense minister, Moscow's court service said Thursday.\n\nA third man has been detained in a bribery case involving a Russian deputy defense minister, Moscow's court service said Thursday.\n\nIt said businessman Alexander Fomin is suspected of paying bribes to Deputy Defense Minister Timur Ivanov, who was detained on Wednesday, as well as Ivanov's associate, Sergei Borodin. All of the men are to remain in custody until at least June 23.\n\nIvanov, an ally of Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu, was jailed pending an investigation and trial on charges of bribery, court officials said in a statement. He was in charge of military construction projects and was previously accused of living a lavish lifestyle in anti-corruption investigations conducted by the team of late Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny.\n\nMoscow's court service said Fomin and Borodin contributed to Ivanov receiving a ''particularly large bribe\" -- an offense punishable by up to 15 years in prison.\n\nIvanov, 48, was sanctioned by both the United States and European Union in 2022 after Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine.\n\nAccording to a court statement, investigators told the judge that Ivanov conspired with third parties to receive a bribe in the form of unspecified property services ''during contracting and subcontracting work for the needs of the Ministry of Defense.''\n\nIvanov's lawyer, Murad Musayev, told the state news agency Tass on Wednesday that his client is accused of ''taking a bribe in the form of free construction and repair work on supposedly his personal properties,'' and in turn providing ''assistance to companies that were contractors for the Defense Ministry.''\n\nAnother lawyer, Denis Baluyev, was quoted by state news agency RIA Novosti as saying Wednesday that Ivanov maintains his innocence.\n\nAccording to the Defense Ministry's website, Ivanov was appointed in 2016 by a presidential decree. He oversaw property management, housing and medical support for the military, as well as construction projects.\n\nRIA Novosti quoted Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov as saying that Shoigu and President Vladimir Putin were informed of Ivanov's arrest, which comes as Moscow's war in Ukraine grinds through its third year.\n\nIndependent Russian news outlets reported Wednesday that the bribery charges were intended to hide more serious charges of treason and avoid scandal, citing two unidentified sources close to the Federal Security Service, or FSB.\n\nPeskov dismissed the suggestion and described the reports as speculation. ''There are a lot of rumors. We need to rely on official information,'' he told journalists.\n\nMusayev, Ivanov's lawyer, also denied any other charges, telling RIA Novosti Ivanov faced only bribery allegations.\n\nBefore his arrest, Ivanov was seen attending a meeting with Shoigu and other top military brass. The move against Ivanov came nearly a month after Putin called on the FSB to ''keep up a systemic anti-corruption effort'' and pay special attention to state defense procurement.\n\nRussian media reported that Ivanov oversaw some of the construction in Mariupol, a Ukrainian port city that was devastated by bombardment and occupied by Russian forces early in the war.\n\nZvezda, the official TV channel of the Russian military, reported in summer 2022 that the ministry was building an entire residential block in Mariupol and showed Ivanov inspecting construction sites and newly erected buildings.\n\nThat same year, the team of opposition leader Navalny alleged Ivanov and his family had been enjoying luxurious trips abroad, lavish parties and owned elite real estate. The activists also alleged that Ivanov's wife, Svetlana, divorced him in 2022 to avoid sanctions and continued living a lavish lifestyle.\n\nThe prosecution of high-level officials for corruption remains relatively rare in Russia.\n\nIn April 2023, former Deputy Culture Minister Olga Yarilova was arrested and charged with embezzling more than 200 million rubles ($2.2 million). Yarilova, who held her post from 2018 to 2022, is on trial and facing a possible seven-year jail term.\n\nFormer Economics Minister Alexei Ulyukayev received an eight-year prison sentence in 2017 for accepting a $2 million bribe from one of Putin's top associates. The high-profile trial was widely seen as part of infighting between Kremlin clans. {"uri": "8095213252", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "15:45:14", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T15:45:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T15:44:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "http://hosted.ap.org/article/e0e3b760df031e26b161d7ed2572864c/russian-deputy-defense-minister-ordered-jailed-pending", "title": "A Russian deputy defense minister is ordered jailed pending trial on bribery charges", "body": "A Russian deputy defense minister in charge of military construction projects and accused of living a lavish lifestyle was ordered jailed Wednesday pending an investigation and trial on charges of bribery, court officials said in a statement.\n\nTimur Ivanov, one of 12 deputy defense ministers, appeared in Moscow's Basmany court Wednesday wearing his military uniform. The ally of Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu was arrested Tuesday evening, Russia's Investigative Committee said in a statement.\n\nThe committee gave no further information, apart from saying Ivanov is suspected of taking an especially large bribe -- an offense punishable by up to 15 years in prison.\n\nThe Kremlin rejected some Russian media reports that Ivanov was suspected of treason.\n\nIvanov, 48, was sanctioned by both the United States and European Union in 2022 after Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine.\n\nAccording to a court statement, investigators told the judge that Ivanov had conspired with third parties to receive a bribe in the form of unspecified property services \"during contracting and subcontracting work for the needs of the Ministry of Defense.\"\n\nAn acquaintance of Ivanov's, identified as Sergei Borodin, also was arrested and ordered jailed pending an investigation and trial on the same charges, court officials said. Both men are to remain in custody until at least June 23.\n\nAccording to the Defense Ministry's website, Ivanov was appointed in 2016 by a presidential decree. He oversaw property management, housing and medical support for the military, as well as construction projects.\n\nRussia's state news agency RIA Novosti quoted Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov as saying that Shoigu and President Vladimir Putin were informed of Ivanov's arrest, which comes as Moscow's war in Ukraine grinds through its third year.\n\nPeskov dismissed Russian media reports that the corruption allegations against Ivanov were intended to obscure additional allegations of high treason.\n\nIndependent Russian news outlet reported that the bribery charges were intended to hide more serious charges of treason and avoid scandal, citing two unidentified sources close to the Federal Security Service, or FSB.\n\nPeskov described the reports as speculation. \"There are a lot of rumors. We need to rely on official information,\" he told journalists.\n\nIvanov's lawyer also denied any other charges, telling RIA Novosti that he faced only bribery allegations.\n\nBefore his arrest, Ivanov was seen attending a meeting with Shoigu and other military brass.\n\nRussian media reported that he oversaw some of the construction in Mariupol -- a Ukrainian port city that was devastated by bombardment and occupied by Russian forces early in the war.\n\nZvezda, the official TV channel of the Russian military, reported in summer 2022 that the ministry was building an entire residential block in Mariupol and showed Ivanov inspecting construction sites and newly erected residential buildings.\n\nThat same year, the team of the late Alexei Navalny, Russia's most prominent opposition leader and anti-corruption campaigner, alleged Ivanov and his family had been enjoying luxurious trips abroad, lavish parties and owning elite real estate. The activists also alleged that Ivanov's wife, Svetlana, divorced him in 2022 to avoid sanctions and continued living a lavish lifestyle.\n\nCommenting on Ivanov's case, Navalny's ally Maria Pevchikh said on social platform X: \"It's a good day today.\"\n\nThe prosecution of high-level officials for corruption remains relatively rare in Russia.\n\nThe most recent arrest in April 2023 saw former Deputy Culture Minister Olga Yarilova charged with embezzling more than 200 million rubles ($2.2 million). Yarilova, who held her post between 2018 and 2022, is on trial and facing a seven-year jail term.\n\nFormer Economics Minister Alexei Ulyukayev received an eight-year prison sentence in 2017 for accepting a $2 million bribe from one of Putin's top associates. The high-profile trial was widely seen as part of infighting between Kremlin clans. Ulyukayev, now 68, was granted early release from prison in May 2022.", "source": {"uri": "hosted.ap.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "Associated Press"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8094895658", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "12:29:40", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T12:29:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T12:29:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.arnnewscentre.ae/en/news/international/russia-detains-ally-of-defence-minister-shoigu-for-corruption/", "title": "Russia detains ally of Defence Minister Shoigu for corruption", "body": "A Russian court on Wednesday ordered one of Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu's deputies be kept in custody on suspicion of taking bribes, the highest-profile corruption case since President Vladimir Putin sent troops into Ukraine in 2022.\n\nDeputy Defence Minister Timur Ivanov was detained on Tuesday at work by the Federal Security Service (FSB), the main successor to the Soviet-era KGB, for accepting large bribes.\n\nMoscow's Basmanny District Court ordered Ivanov to be kept in custody until June 23. Ivanov, 48, dressed in his uniform, was shown standing in a glass cage in court, frowning slightly, footage released by the court service showed.\n\n\"The investigation believes that Ivanov entered into a criminal conspiracy with third parties, teamed up with them in advance to commit an organised crime by an organised group,\" the court service said.\n\nThe conspiracy was to receive \"property and services on a particularly large scale during contract and sub-contract work for the ministry of defence,\" the court service said.\n\nRussian media said he denied being guilty. He faces 15 years in jail if convicted. State media gave the case full coverage.\n\nThe sudden arrest of an ally of Shoigu, who Putin tasked with fighting the war in Ukraine, triggered speculation about a battle within the elite and of a public crackdown on the corruption which has plagued Russia's post-Soviet armed forces.\n\nSome Russian bloggers, who have long accused senior generals of incompetence, rejoiced at the apparent fall of a top military official long linked to the ostentatious opulence which Putin has made clear he does not want to see displayed in wartime.\n\nSome said the arrest could be a public lesson for the elite, though others said it was a blow for Shoigu, a close Putin ally and one of Russia's most powerful men.\n\nThe Kremlin said Putin had been informed, and added that Shoigu had also been told. The defence ministry made no comment. A close friend of Ivanov's, Sergei Borodin, was also charged with conspiring to take bribes.\n\nOSTENTATIOUS WEALTH\n\nIvanov, who has served as deputy minister since 2016, was in charge of property management, housing, construction and mortgages at the defence ministry - whose spending has spiralled since the start of the war.\n\nIvanov had long been the subject of journalistic investigations which alleged he and his family lived a lavish lifestyle complete with visits to Europe's most expensive boutiques and an array of deluxe real estate.\n\nIn 2022, Russia's Anti-Corruption Foundation, headed by the late Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny, investigated Ivanov.\n\nIt alleged that he and his family lived a life of luxury including yachts, helicopters, visits to French Riviera, purchases of diamonds and even a 19th Century mansion on one of Moscow's most elegant streets.\n\nForbes magazine listed Ivanov as one of the wealthiest men in Russia's security structures. Other investigations alleged corruption in Russia's reconstruction of Mariupol, the Ukrainian city on the Sea of Azov that is controlled by Russian forces.\n\nIvanov was unable to comment as he was in detention. Putin last month ordered the FSB to root out corruption in state defence procurement.\n\nIvanov, who graduated with a degree in mathematics from Moscow State University, rose through the ranks of Russia's state atomic energy sector before moving to become the deputy head of Moscow region's government under Shoigu, who was then governor.\n\nSome Russian military bloggers have long accused top generals of corruption, especially after the army's hurried withdrawal from parts of Ukraine after over-extending itself during the first days of the invasion.", "source": {"uri": "arnnewscentre.ae", The statute that the investigators cited for his detention is for accepting bribes \"on a particularly large scale\". He faces 15 years in jail if convicted. The sudden arrest of an ally of Shoigu, who Putin tasked with fighting the war in Ukraine, triggered speculation about a battle within the elite and of a public crackdown on the corruption which has plagued Russia's post-Soviet armed forces.\n\nThe Kremlin said Putin had been informed, and added that Shoigu had also been told. Ivanov was present earlier on Tuesday at a meeting of top defence officials chaired by Shoigu.\n\nIvanov, who has served as deputy minister since 2016, was in charge of property management, housing, construction and mortgages at the defence ministry. The defence ministry has made no comment.\n\nRussia's Kommersant newspaper said that Ivanov, 48, was arrested by the Federal Security Service (FSB), the successor to the Soviet-era KGB which Putin last month told to root out corruption in state defence procurement.\n\nThe Izvestia newspaper said others had also been detained, though there was no official confirmation of that. The newspaper said Ivanov's properties were being searched. State television gave the case full coverage.\n\n\"Lets just say the investigation did not start yesterday, the day before yesterday or even a month ago,\" an unidentified Russia law enforcement source told the TASS state news agency. FSB military counter-intelligence was involved, TASS said.\n\nIt was not immediately clear why such a senior official with a close association with Shoigu would be targeted.\n\nRussian military bloggers have long accused top generals of corruption and incompetence, especially after the army's hurried withdrawal from parts of Ukraine after seriously over-extending itself during the first days of the invasion.\n\nWithin the Russian elite, there are a range of views on the war, which has had touched off the worst breakdown in relations between Russia and the West since the 1962 Cuban Missile Crisis.\n\nIvanov, who could not be reached as he was in detention, has long been linked to the ostentatious opulence which has characterised some sections of the post-Soviet Russian elite, including luxurious real estate and flashy parties.\n\nIn 2022, Russia's Anti-Corruption Foundation, headed by the late Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny, alleged that Ivanov and his family led a lavish lifestyle.\n\nIvanov, who was born in Moscow, graduated with a degree in mathematics from Moscow State University and completed a dissertation in the organisational models for the construction of nuclear power plants.\n\nHe rose through the ranks of Russia's state atomic energy sector and worked as an adviser to the energy minister before moving to become the deputy head of Moscow region's government under Shoigu, who was then governor.\n\nFrom 2013, Ivanov headed a defence ministry construction company which builds housing for soldiers and at high-security installations.", "source": European Union in 2022, after Russia invaded Ukraine.\n\nRussia's state news agency RIA Novosti quoted Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov as saying that both President Vladimir Putin and Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu were informed about the arrest.\n\nThe Investigative Committee, Russia's top law enforcement agency, reported Ivanov's detention without offering any details of the accusations against him, saying only that he is suspected of taking an especially large bribe -- a criminal offense punishable by up to 15 years in prison.\n\nAccording to the defense ministry's website, Ivanov was appointed to the post in 2016 by a presidential decree and oversaw property management, housing and medical support for the military, construction and reconstruction of facilities.\n\nRussian media {"uri": "8094422820", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "07:50:04", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T07:50:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T07:49:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.indiatvnews.com/news/world/russian-deputy-defence-minister-timur-ivanov-arrested-on-bribery-charges-sergei-shoigu-2024-04-24-927736", "title": "Russian deputy Defence Minister Timur Ivanov arrested for accepting bribes 'on a particularly large scale'", "body": "A Russian court on Wednesday formally arrested Deputy Defence Minister Timur Ivanov and charged him with bribery, the court said, following his detention on Tuesday. The court remanded Ivanov in custody for two months and said that according to the charges he had put himself in a position to benefit from hiring contractors for the ministry where he oversaw construction activities.\n\nThe sudden arrest of an ally of Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu, whom President Vladimir Putin tasked with fighting the war in Ukraine, triggered speculation about a battle within the elite and of a public crackdown on the corruption which has plagued Russia's post-Soviet armed forces. The Kremlin said Putin had been informed, and added that Shoigu had also been told. Ivanov was present earlier on Tuesday at a meeting of top defence officials chaired by Shoigu.\n\nIvanov, who has served as deputy minister since 2016, was in charge of property management, housing, construction and mortgages at the defence ministry. The defence ministry has made no comment.\n\nRussia's Kommersant newspaper said that Ivanov, 48, was arrested by the Federal Security Service (FSB), the successor to the Soviet-era KGB which Putin last month told to root out corruption in state defence procurement. The Izvestia newspaper said others had also been detained, though there was no official confirmation of that. The newspaper said Ivanov's properties were being searched. State television gave the case full coverage.\n\n\"Let's just say the investigation did not start yesterday, the day before yesterday or even a month ago,\" an unidentified Russian law enforcement source told the TASS state news agency. FSB military counter-intelligence was involved, TASS said. It was not immediately clear why such a senior official with a close association with Shoigu would be targeted.\n\nRussian military bloggers have long accused top generals of corruption and incompetence, especially after the army's hurried withdrawal from parts of Ukraine after seriously over-extending itself during the first days of the invasion. Within the Russian elite, there are a range of views on the war, which has had touched off the worst breakdown in relations between Russia and the West since the 1962 Cuban Missile Crisis.\n\nIvanov, who could not be reached as he was in detention, has long been linked to the ostentatious opulence which has characterised some sections of the post-Soviet Russian elite, including luxurious real estate and flashy parties.\n\nIn 2022, Russia's Anti-Corruption Foundation, headed by the late Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny, alleged that Ivanov and his family led a lavish lifestyle. Ivanov, who was born in Moscow, graduated with a degree in mathematics from Moscow State University and completed a dissertation on the organisational models for the construction of nuclear power plants.\n\nHe rose through the ranks of Russia's state atomic energy sector and worked as an adviser to the energy minister before moving to become the deputy head of the Moscow region's government under Shoigu, who was then governor.\n\nFrom 2013, Ivanov headed a defence ministry construction company which builds housing for soldiers and high-security installations. Forbes magazine listed Ivanov as one of the wealthiest men in Russia's security structures.\n\n(With inputs from agency)", "source": {"uri": "indiatvnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "India TV {"uri": "2024-04-335137555", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "11:57:53", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T11:57:53Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T08:38:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://tribtown.com/2024/04/25/third-man-is-detained-in-a-major-bribery-case-that-involves-russias-deputy-defense-minister/", "title": "Third man is detained in a major bribery case that involves Russia's deputy defense minister", "body": "A third man has been detained in a bribery case involving one of Russia's most senior defense officials, Moscow's court service said Thursday.\n\nIt said businessman Alexander Fomin is suspected of paying bribes to Deputy Defense Minister Timur Ivanov, who was detained on Wednesday, as well as Ivanov's associate, Sergei Borodin. All of the men are to remain in custody until at least June 23.\n\nIt is rare for such a high-ranking official to be accused of a crime in Russia. Ivanov, an ally of Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu, was jailed pending an investigation and trial on charges of bribery, court officials said in a statement. He was in charge of military construction projects and was previously accused of living a lavish lifestyle in anti-corruption investigations conducted by the team of late Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny. It is unclear what sparked the decision to charge him with bribery.\n\nIvanov, 48, was sanctioned by both the United States and European Union in 2022 after Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine. President Putin's spokesperson, Dmitry Peskov, said Wednesday that the construction projects that were overseen by Ivanov will continue.\n\nMoscow's court service said Fomin and Borodin contributed to Ivanov receiving a \"particularly large bribe\" -- an offense punishable by up to 15 years in prison. As part of the case against Fomin and the deputy minister, the courts service added that Fomin did not pay for goods, work and services related to repairing and reconstructing buildings.\n\nRussian state news agency Tass reported Wednesday that a Moscow businessman whose company is involved in construction gave testimony which incriminated the deputy defense minister. Tass did not name the individual who gave the evidence, but public records and Russian newspapers say that Alexander Fomin owns half of the company, called Olimpsitistroy.\n\nIn 2021, Ivanov awarded Fomin and the co-owner of Olimpsitistroy a state award called For Merit to the Fatherland for building medical centers, the Russian newspaper Kommersant reported.\n\nAccording to a court statement Wednesday, investigators told the judge that Ivanov conspired with third parties to receive a bribe in the form of unspecified property services \"during contracting and subcontracting work for the needs of the Ministry of Defense.\"\n\nIvanov's lawyer, Murad Musayev, told the state news agency Tass on Wednesday that his client is accused of \"taking a bribe in the form of free construction and repair work on supposedly his personal properties,\" and in turn providing \"assistance to companies that were contractors for the Defense Ministry.\"\n\nAnother lawyer, Denis Baluyev, was quoted by state news agency RIA Novosti as saying Wednesday that Ivanov maintains his innocence.\n\nAccording to the Defense Ministry's website, Ivanov was appointed in 2016 by a presidential decree. He oversaw property management, housing and medical support for the military, as well as construction projects.\n\nRIA Novosti quoted Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov as saying that Shoigu and President Vladimir Putin were informed of Ivanov's arrest, which comes as Moscow's war in Ukraine grinds through its third year.\n\nIndependent Russian news outlets reported Wednesday that the bribery charges were intended to hide more serious charges of treason and avoid scandal, citing two unidentified sources close to the Federal Security Service, or FSB.\n\nPeskov dismissed the suggestion and described the reports as speculation. \"There are a lot of rumors. We need to rely on official information,\" he told journalists.\n\nMusayev, Ivanov's lawyer, also denied any other charges, telling RIA Novosti Ivanov faced only bribery allegations.\n\nBefore his arrest, Ivanov was seen attending a meeting with Shoigu and other top military brass. The move against Ivanov came nearly a month after Putin called on the FSB to \"keep up a systemic anti-corruption effort\" and pay special attention to state defense procurement.\n\nRussian media reported that Ivanov oversaw some of the construction in Mariupol, a Ukrainian port city that was devastated by bombardment and occupied by Russian forces early in the war.\n\nZvezda, the official TV channel of the Russian military, reported in summer 2022 that the ministry was building an entire residential block in Mariupol and showed Ivanov inspecting construction sites and newly erected buildings.\n\nThat same year, the team of opposition leader Navalny alleged Ivanov and his family had been enjoying luxurious trips abroad, lavish parties and owned elite real estate. The activists also alleged that Ivanov's wife, Svetlana, divorced him in 2022 to avoid sanctions and continued living a lavish lifestyle.\n\nFew high-level officials have been prosecuted in Russia.\n\nIn April 2023, former Deputy Culture Minister Olga Yarilova was arrested and charged with embezzling more than 200 million rubles ($2.2 million). Yarilova, who held her post from 2018 to 2022, is on trial and facing a possible seven-year jail term.\n\nFormer Economics Minister Alexei Ulyukayev received an eight-year prison sentence in 2017 for accepting a $2 million bribe from one of Putin's top associates. The high-profile trial was widely seen as part of infighting between Kremlin clans. Ulyukayev, now 68, was granted early release from prison in May 2022.", "source": {"uri": "tribtown.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Tribune"}, "authors": [{"uri": {"uri": "8094569395", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "09:18:57", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T09:18:57Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T09:18:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/law-order/2905958-russia-detains-ally-of-defence-minister-shoigu-for-corruption", "title": "Russia detains ally of Defence Minister Shoigu for corruption | Law-Order", "body": "A Russian court on Wednesday ordered one of Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu's deputies be kept in custody on suspicion of taking bribes, the highest-profile corruption case since President Vladimir Putin sent troops into Ukraine in 2022. Deputy Defence Minister Timur Ivanov was detained on Tuesday at work by the Federal Security Service (FSB), the main successor to the Soviet-era KGB, for accepting large bribes.\n\nMoscow's Basmanny District Court ordered Ivanov be kept in custody until June 23. Ivanov, 48, dressed in his uniform, was shown standing in a glass cage in court, frowning slightly, footage released by the court service showed. \"The investigation believes that Ivanov entered into a criminal conspiracy with third parties, teamed up with them in advance to commit an organised crime by an organised group,\" the court service said.\n\nThe conspiracy was to receive \"property and services on a particularly large scale during contract and sub-contract work for the ministry of defence,\" the court service said. Russian media said he denied being guilty. He faces 15 years in jail if convicted. State media gave the case full coverage.\n\nThe sudden arrest of an ally of Shoigu, who Putin tasked with fighting the war in Ukraine, triggered speculation about a battle within the elite and of a public crackdown on the corruption which has plagued Russia's post-Soviet armed forces. Some Russian bloggers, who have long accused senior generals of incompetence, rejoiced at the apparent fall of a top military official long linked to the ostentatious opulence which Putin has made clear he does not want to see displayed in wartime.\n\nSome said the arrest could be a public lesson for the elite, though others said it was a blow for Shoigu, a close Putin ally and one of Russia's most powerful men. The Kremlin said Putin had been informed, and added that Shoigu had also been told. The defence ministry made no comment. A close friend of Ivanov's, Sergei Borodin, was also charged with conspiring to take bribes.\n\nOSTENTATIOUS WEALTH Ivanov, who has served as deputy minister since 2016, was in charge of property management, housing, construction and mortgages at the defence ministry - whose spending has spiralled since the start of the war.\n\n\"Lets just say the investigation did not start yesterday, the day before yesterday or even a month ago,\" an unidentified Russian law enforcement source told the TASS state news agency. FSB military counter-intelligence was involved, TASS said. Ivanov had long been the subject of journalistic investigations which alleged he and his family lived a lavish lifestyle complete with visits to Europe's most expensive boutiques and an array of deluxe real estate.\n\nIn 2022, Russia's Anti-Corruption Foundation, headed by the late Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny, investigated Ivanov. It alleged that he and his family lived a life of luxury including yachts, helicopters, visits to French Riviera, purchases of diamonds and even a 19th Century mansion on one of Moscow's most elegant streets.\n\nForbes magazine listed Ivanov as one of the wealthiest men in Russia's security structures. Other investigations alleged corruption in Russia's reconstruction of Mariupol, the Ukrainian city on the Sea of Azov that is controlled by Russian forces. Ivanov was unable to comment as he was in detention. Putin last month ordered the FSB to root out corruption in state defence procurement.\n\nIvanov, who graduated with a degree in mathematics from Moscow State University, rose through the ranks of Russia's state atomic energy sector before moving to become the deputy head of Moscow region's government under Shoigu, who was then governor. Some Russian military bloggers have long accused top generals of corruption, especially after the army's hurried withdrawal from parts of Ukraine after over-extending itself during the first days of the invasion.\n\n\"It is clear that this is a tectonic shift,\" said Yuri Podolyaka, one of the most popular pro-Russian military bloggers. \"And this is not about Ivanov... I hope this is only the beginning.\"\n\n(This story has not been edited by Devdiscourse staff and is auto-generated from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "devdiscourse.com", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8095729583", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "23:06:03", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T23:06:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T23:05:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.citizen.co.za/?p=3596713", "title": "Russian deputy defence minister held over bribery accusations | The Citizen", "body": "A Russian deputy defence minister exposed in an investigation by late opposition leader Alexei Navalny's team was remanded in custody Wednesday on suspicion of taking large bribes.\n\nThe arrest of Timur Ivanov, a long-time ally of Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu, is the most dramatic corruption case in Russia in recent years. It comes as spending on the military has ballooned amid its offensive on Ukraine.\n\nIvanov, 48, oversaw construction and procurement for the armed forces, and was linked to Russia's high-profile rebuilding of the Ukrainian city of Mariupol, occupied by Moscow's forces.\n\n\"The deputy defence minister of the Russian Federation was sent to a pre-trial detention centre,\" the press service for Moscow courthouses said in a statement on social media.\n\nHe faces up to 15 years in prison for bribe-taking \"on a particularly large scale\", it added.\n\nALSO READ: Two detained in Poland for attack on Navalny ally: Lithuania president\n\nIvanov denies the charges, his lawyer told the state-run TASS news agency.\n\nSeveral independent Russian media outlets have alleged that Ivanov and his family acquired vast wealth through kick-backs on contracts he agreed at the ministry.\n\nIn December 2022, Navalny's team said they had obtained thousands of leaked emails from Ivanov's wife, Svetlana Maniovich, that showed a lavish lifestyle well beyond what his official salary could cover.\n\nThey said she had spent hundreds of thousands of euros on luxury cars, jewellery, clothes, parties, and renting premium property and yachts in the south of France.\n\nSome of the transactions were routed through third parties, including defence ministry contractors, they alleged.\n\nALSO READ: International reactions after Israel's reported attack on Iran\n\nThe Kremlin said President Vladimir Putin was in \"constant\" contact with Shoigu but refused to comment directly on Ivanov's arrest.\n\n\"There will be an investigation,\" spokesman Dmitry Peskov said, cautioning against \"speculation\".\n\nIn court on Wednesday, Ivanov, 48, stood in a glass dock for defendants in military uniform.\n\nThe court said investigators believe he was part of a \"criminal conspiracy\" to take a \"bribe on a particularly large scale in the form of property services, during the course of contracting and subcontracting work for the defence ministry.\"\n\nThe judge sent him to pre-trial detention until at least June 23. He will be held at the notorious Lefortovo jail in Moscow, TASS reported.\n\nCampaigners, including Navalny, have long argued that corruption is endemic in Putin's Russia.\n\nArrests of high-profile government figures are rare, usually the result of political infighting, analysts say.\n\nActivists say the vast sums being poured into the Ukraine offensive has given officials new opportunities to enrich themselves through secretive procurement deals.\n\nRussian military bloggers, who have long criticised Shoigu's handling of the offensive, quickly linked Ivanov to the defence minister on social media.\n\nALSO READ: Russian peacekeepers started withdrawal from Nagorno-Karabakh: Kremlin\n\nIn a post criticising Ivanov, Wagner-linked Telegram channel Grey Zone repeatedly referred to him as \"Shoigu's Deputy\".\n\n\"He, like Shoigu, comes from the family clan,\" it said.\n\nFormer Wagner boss Yevgeny Prigozhin had accused Shoigu and other defence ministry officials of corruption and incompetence before his mysterious death last year.\n\nThe defence ministry has not commented on Ivanov's arrest.\n\nJust hours before investigators announced they had arrested Ivanov on Tuesday he {"uri": "8095248795", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "16:08:34", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T16:08:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T16:08:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://nationnews.com/2024/04/24/russian-deputy-defence-minister-timur-ivanov-accused-of-taking-bribes/", "title": "Russian deputy defence minister Timur Ivanov accused of taking bribes - nationnews.com", "body": "A Russian deputy defence minister has been accused of taking bribes and remanded in custody by a court in Moscow.\n\nTimur Ivanov, who denies the charges, is accused of accepting bribes \"on a particularly large scale\".\n\nAppointed to the defence ministry in 2016, Mr Ivanov, 47, has been responsible for Russia's military infrastructure projects.\n\nActivists have long criticised the levels of alleged corruption in Russia.\n\nHowever, such high profile cases have been rare since the start of Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine in 2022.\n\nMr Ivanov is considered an ally of Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu and has worked with him for many years. He was previously deputy prime minister of the Moscow region, where Mr Shoigu briefly served as governor.\n\nThe Kremlin has rejected reports in some Russian media that the real reason for Mr Ivanov's arrest was that he was suspected of treason.\n\n\"There are many different interpretations around all this now... You need to focus on official information,\" spokesman Dmitry Peskov told reporters.\n\nHe also stated that President Vladimir Putin had been notified of Mr Ivanov's detention in advance.\n\nIn 2022, the Anti-Corruption Foundation (ACF), the group founded by late opposition leader Alexei Navalny, accused Mr Ivanov of participating in \"corruption schemes during construction in the territories of Ukraine occupied by Russia\".\n\nIn particular, it said he had profited from construction projects in the Ukrainian port city of Mariupol, much of which was destroyed by Russian bombing in the months following the full-scale invasion of Ukraine.\n\nBasmanny district court in Moscow remanded him in jail for two months on charges of entering into a criminal conspiracy with third parties in his role of supervising the construction and overhaul of defence ministry facilities.\n\nIf found guilty he could face up to 15 years in jail. A second man, Sergei Borodin, who was described as a friend of the Mr Ivanov, also appeared in court on Moscow on similar charges.\n\nMr Ivanov denied the allegations made against him by Russia's Investigative Committee. The section of Russia's criminal code under which Mr Ivanov was detained - Part 6 of article 290 - applies when a suspected bribe exceeds one million roubles (\u00a38,620; $10,700).\n\nMr Ivanov's arrest marks a rare move against a member of Russia's governing elite, many of whom are believed to have used their positions to amass vast personal fortunes.\n\nSome Russian commentators have said the arrest will be a blow to Mr Shoigu. \"If he can't manage it, he will be next to fall. This person is 100% his man,\" one anonymous source told a popular military Telegram channel.\n\nMr Ivanov has been sanctioned by the US and UK and is the subject of a travel ban and asset freeze imposed by the European Union, which describes him as being \"tenth in the overall hierarchy of the Russian military leadership\".", "source": {"uri": "nationnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title":
