{"uri": "8093819734", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-23", "time": "21:53:49", "dateTime": "2024-04-23T21:53:49Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-23T21:53:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://kyivindependent.com/russias-deputy-defense-minister-detained-on-suspicions-of-bribery/", "title": "Russia's deputy defense minister detained on suspicions of bribery", "body": "Support independent journalism in Ukraine. Join us in this fight.\n\nRussia's Deputy Defense Minister Timur Ivanov was detained on April 23 on the suspicion of receiving a bribe, Russia's Investigative Committee announced.\n\nIvanov, who is Russia's top official in charge of the country's construction of military facilities, was detained under part six of Article 290 of Russia's criminal code. According to Russian state media outlet TASS, the specific provision under the Criminal Code pertains to bribes over 1 million rubles.\n\nRussia's Investigative Committee noted that an investigation is ongoing and did not provide any details on the allegations.\n\nThe Investigative Committee said that it will petition for Ivanov's arrest. If convicted, Ivanov would face up to 15 years in prison.\n\nIvanov, who has been sanctioned by various Western countries due to his role in Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine, was previously the target of a December 2022 investigation by the Anti-Corruption Foundation, founded by Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny. The investigation alleged that Ivanov profited from construction projects in occupied Mariupol.\n\nA staunch opponent of corruption and Russian President Vladimir Putin, Navalny died on Feb. 16, 2024 after was being held in a penal colony in Russia's far northern Yamal-Nenets Autonomous District. {"uri": "8094409391", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "07:41:06", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T07:41:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T07:40:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7647058963775635, "url": "https://www.perthnow.com.au/news/conflict/russia-deputy-defence-minister-arrested-over-bribery-c-14428380", "title": "Russia deputy defence minister arrested over bribery", "body": "Russia's deputy defence minister has been formally arrested and charged with bribery, a Russian court says.\n\nThe court remanded Deputy Defence Minister Timur Ivanov in custody for two months and said according to the charges he had put himself in a position to benefit from hiring contractors for the ministry where he oversaw construction activities.\n\nIvanov was detained on Tuesday, according to a brief 22-word statement by Russia's investigative committee.\n\nThe statute that the investigators cited for his detention is for accepting bribes \"on a particularly large scale\".\n\nHe faces 15 years in jail if convicted.\n\nThe sudden arrest of an ally of Shoigu, who Putin tasked with fighting the war in Ukraine, triggered speculation about a battle within the elite and of a public crackdown on the corruption that has plagued Russia's post-Soviet armed forces.\n\nThe Kremlin said Putin had been informed, and added that Shoigu had also been told. Ivanov was present earlier on Tuesday at a meeting of top defence officials chaired by Shoigu.\n\nIvanov, who has served as deputy minister since 2016, was in charge of property management, housing, construction and mortgages at the defence ministry. The defence ministry has made no comment.\n\nRussia's Kommersant newspaper said that Ivanov, 48, was arrested by the Federal Security Service (FSB), the successor to the Soviet-era KGB which Putin last month told to root out corruption in state defence procurement.\n\nThe Izvestia newspaper said others had also been detained, though there was no official confirmation of that. The newspaper said Ivanov's properties were being searched. State television gave the case full coverage.\n\n\"Let's just say the investigation did not start yesterday, the day before yesterday or even a month ago,\" an unidentified Russian law enforcement source told the TASS state news agency. FSB military counter-intelligence was involved, TASS said.\n\nIt was not immediately clear why such a senior official with a close association with Shoigu would be targeted.\n\nRussian military bloggers have long accused top generals of corruption and incompetence, especially after the army's hurried withdrawal from parts of Ukraine after seriously over-extending itself during the first days of the invasion.\n\nIvanov, who could not be reached as he was in detention, has long been linked to the ostentatious opulence that has characterised some sections of the post-Soviet Russian elite, including luxurious real estate and flashy parties.\n\nIn 2022, Russia's Anti-Corruption Foundation, headed by the late Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny, alleged that Ivanov and his family led a lavish lifestyle.\n\nForbes magazine listed Ivanov as one of the wealthiest men in Russia's security structures.", "source": {"uri": "perthnow.com.au", "dataType": "news", "title": "Perth Now"}, lifestyle.\n\nIvanov, who was born in Moscow, graduated with a degree in mathematics from Moscow State University and completed a dissertation in the organizational models for the construction of nuclear power plants.\n\nHe rose through the ranks of Russia's state atomic energy sector and worked as an adviser to the energy minister before moving to become the deputy head of Moscow region's "STORY: In a glass cage in a Moscow court stands Russia's Deputy Defense Minister Timur Ivanov on Wednesday (April 24), a day after he was arrested at work for accepting large bribes.\n\nThe court remanded him in custody for two months and said Ivanov entered into a criminal conspiracy with third parties to receive property and services while working for the ministry of defense.\n\nIvanov, deputy minister since 2016, was in charge of property management, housing, construction and mortgages.\n\nThe defense ministry, whose spending has spiraled since the start of the war, has made no comment.\n\nAs the right hand man of Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu, Ivanov's detention is the highest profile corruption case since Russia sent troops into Ukraine in February 2022.\n\nThe Kremlin said President Vladimir Putin had been informed, and Shoigu had also been told.\n\nIvanov was present earlier on Tuesday at a meeting of top defense officials chaired by Shoigu.\n\nIt's triggered speculation about a battle within the elite to crackdown on corruption that has plagued Russia's post-Soviet armed forces.\n\nRussia's Kommersant newspaper said Ivanov was arrested by the Federal Security Service (FSB), the successor to the KGB which Putin last month told to root out corruption in state defense procurement.\n\nIvanov has been the subject of journalistic investigations which {"uri": "8096553916", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "10:40:51", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T10:40:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T10:40:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://kyivindependent.com/russian-media-russian-deputy-defense-minister-ivanov-accused-of-bribery-stripped-of-his-position-assets/", "title": "Russian media: Russian deputy defense minister detained for bribery stripped of his position, assets", "body": "Support independent journalism in Ukraine. Join us in this fight.\n\nRussian Deputy Defense Minister Timur Ivanov, who was detained the previous day on suspicion of receiving a bribe, was ordered to be dismissed from his position and had his assets seized, the state-run media outlet TASS reported on April 25.\n\nIvanov, Russia's top official in charge of the country's construction of military facilities, was initially detained under part six of Article 290 of Russia's criminal code. According to TASS, the specific provision under the criminal code pertains to bribes over 1 million rubles (~$10,000).\n\nRussia's Investigative Committee noted that an investigation is ongoing and did not provide any details on the allegations.\n\nLaw enforcement agencies told TASS that \"everything that is registered to (Ivanov) and his wife, as well as to his ex-wives and five children, including adopted ones, (and) all this property has already been seized\" for the purpose of interim measures should Ivanov be convicted.\n\nSeparately, Defense Minister Sergey Shoigu signed an order to remove Ivanov from his position.\n\nIf found guilty, Ivanov could be sentenced to up to 15 years in prison. The accusations toward Ivanov form what is likely the highest-profile corruption case in Russia since the beginning of the full-scale war against Ukraine.\n\nVarious Western countries have sanctioned Ivanov due to his role in Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine, and he was previously the target of a December 2022 investigation by the Anti-Corruption Foundation, founded by late Russian {"uri": "8094226473", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "05:31:16", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T05:31:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T05:30:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://theprint.in/world/russian-deputy-defence-minister-detained-on-bribe-allegations-officials-say/2054292/", "title": "Russian deputy defence minister detained on bribe allegations, officials say", "body": "The statute that the investigators cited for the detention of Ivanov, who has been in his job for eight years, is for accepting bribes \"on a particularly large scale\".\n\nIn 2022, Russia's Anti-Corruption Foundation, headed by the late Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny, alleged that Ivanov and his family led a lavish lifestyle filled with spending on real estate, luxurious trips and designer clothing.\n\nRussian media reported that Ivanov was in charge, among other things, of large construction projects rebuilding the eastern Ukrainian city of Mariupol, which was heavily bombarded and taken by Russia as part of Moscow's invasion of Ukraine.\n\nKremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov, quoted by Russian news agencies, said a report on Ivanov's detention had been presented to President Vladimir Putin. Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu had been informed in advance of his detention, he said.\n\nThe daily Izvestia reported on Wednesday, citing sources, that searches were conducted late on Tuesday at some of Ivanov's properties.\n\nRussian news reports said that Ivanov, if convicted, could face up to 15 years in prison.\n\nForbes magazine listed Ivanov, an expert in cybernetics and the nuclear industry, as one of the wealthiest men in Russia's security structures.\n\nNews outlet RBK posted a picture of him attending a meeting of ministerial officials earlier on Tuesday chaired by Shoigu.\n\nRussian news reports said Ivanov was likely the most senior Russian official to face such charges since Moscow launched its invasion of Ukraine in February 2022.\n\nHe worked in companies dealing with fuel and energy and in the Moscow regional government before joining the defence ministry in 2010. {"uri": "8094950541", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "13:03:01", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T13:03:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T13:02:36Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.lemonde.fr/en/international/article/2024/04/24/russian-minister-detained-over-bribery-accusations-says-moscow-law-enforcement_6669387_4.html", "title": "Russian minister detained over bribery accusations, says Moscow law enforcement", "body": "A Russian deputy defense minister exposed in an investigation by late opposition leader Alexei Navalny's team was remanded in custody Wednesday, April 24, on suspicion of taking large bribes.\n\nTimur Ivanov, 48, oversaw construction and procurement for the armed forces, and was linked to Russia's high-profile rebuilding of the Ukrainian city of Mariupol, occupied by Moscow's forces. \"The deputy defense minister of the Russian Federation was sent to a pre-trial detention center,\" the press service for Moscow courthouses said in a statement on social media.\n\nThe arrest of Ivanov, a long-time ally of Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu, is the most dramatic corruption case in Russia in recent years. It comes as spending on the military has ballooned amid its offensive on Ukraine.\n\nHe faces up to 15 years in prison for bribe-taking \"on a particularly large scale,\" it added. Ivanov denies the charges, his lawyer told the state-run TASS news agency. Several independent Russian media outlets have alleged that Ivanov and his family acquired vast wealth through kick-backs on contracts he agreed at the ministry.\n\nIn December 2022, Navalny's team said they had obtained thousands of leaked emails from Ivanov's wife, Svetlana Maniovich, that showed a lavish lifestyle well beyond what his official salary could cover.\n\nThey said she had spent hundreds of thousands of euros on luxury cars, jewelry, clothes, parties, and renting premium property and yachts in the south of France. Some of the transactions were routed through third parties, including defense ministry contractors, they alleged.\n\nThe Kremlin said President Vladimir Putin was in \"constant\" contact with Shoigu but refused to comment directly on Ivanov's arrest. \"There will be an investigation,\" spokesman Dmitry Peskov said, cautioning against \"speculation.\"\n\nIn court on Wednesday, Ivanov, 48, stood in a glass dock for defendants in military uniform. The court said investigators believe he was part of a \"criminal conspiracy\" to take a \"bribe on a particularly large scale in the form of property services, during the course of contracting and subcontracting work for the defense ministry.\" It did not provide further details.\n\nThe judge sent him to pre-trial detention until at least June 23. He will be held at the notorious Lefortovo jail in Moscow, TASS reported.\n\nCampaigners, including Navalny, have long argued that corruption is endemic in Putin's Russia. Arrests of high-profile government figures are rare, usually the result of political infighting, analysts say.\n\nActivists say the vast sums being poured into the Ukraine offensive has given officials new opportunities to enrich themselves through secretive procurement deals.\n\nRussian military bloggers, who have long criticized Shoigu's handling of the offensive, quickly linked Ivanov to the defense minister on social media. In a post criticizing Ivanov, Wagner-linked Telegram channel Grey Zone repeatedly referred to him as \"Shoigu's Deputy.\" \"He, like Shoigu, comes from the family clan,\" it said. Former Wagner boss Yevgeny Prigozhin had accused Shoigu and other defense ministry officials of corruption and incompetence before his mysterious death last year.\n\nThe defense ministry has not commented on Ivanov's arrest.\n\nJust hours before investigators announced they had arrested Ivanov on Tuesday he had appeared in video footage published by the ministry in which Shoigu addressed top military brass about the state of the Ukraine offensive.", "source": {"uri": "lemonde.fr", "dataType": "news", "title": "Le Monde.fr"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": Videos released by state-run news outlet RIA Novosti showed Ivanov standing inside a glass box in a Moscow courtroom.\n\nThe report by US-broadcaster CNN said Ivanov is one the key architects of Russia's so-called military operation in Ukraine. Due to his role in the ongoing war, he has become the subject of European Union and US sanctions.\n\nThe report also pointed out that this is the highest-profile Russian corruption case since the war began in February 2022.\n\nThe conspiracy was to receive \"property and services on a particularly large scale during contract and sub-contract work for the ministry of defence,\" the court service said.\n\nRussian media said he denied being guilty.\n\nIvanov was tasked with the reconstruction of Russian-occupied Mariupol, in southeastern Ukraine and said that he was a frequent fixture at ribbon-cutting ceremonies on construction projects in the war-ravaged city.\n\nLate Kremlin and Putin critic Alexey Navalny's International Anti-Corruption Foundation (ACF) had earlier accused Ivanov of corruption. {"uri": "8094374796", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "07:17:16", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T07:17:16Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T07:17:07Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7568627595901489, "url": "https://economictimes.indiatimes.com/news/defence/russia-detains-deputy-of-defence-minister-shoigu-for-corruption/articleshow/109555296.cms", "title": "Russia detains deputy of defence minister Shoigu for corruption", "body": "Russian security services detained Deputy Defence Minister Timur Ivanov on suspicion of accepting major bribes, marking the highest-profile corruption case since Russia's intervention in Ukraine in February 2022. Ivanov faces charges under a statute for accepting bribes \"on a particularly large scale,\" which could lead to a 15-year jail term if convicted.Russian security services detained one of Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu's deputies on suspicion of taking major bribes, the highest-profile corruption case since President Vladimir Putin sent troops into Ukraine in February 2022.\n\nDeputy Defence Minister Timur Ivanov was detained on Tuesday, according to a brief 22-word statement by Russia's investigative committee. The statute that the investigators cited for his detention is for accepting bribes \"on a particularly large scale\".\n\nHe faces 15 years in jail if convicted.\n\nThe sudden arrest of an ally of Shoigu, who Putin tasked with fighting the war in Ukraine, triggered speculation about a battle within the elite and of a public crackdown on the corruption which has plagued Russia's post-Soviet armed forces.\n\nThe Kremlin said Putin had been informed, and added that Shoigu had also been told. Ivanov was present earlier on Tuesday at a meeting of top defence officials chaired by Shoigu.\n\nIvanov, who has served as deputy minister since 2016, was in charge of property management, housing, construction and mortgages at the defence ministry. The defence ministry has made no comment.\n\nRussia's Kommersant newspaper said that Ivanov, 48, was arrested by the Federal Security Service (FSB), the successor to the Soviet-era KGB which Putin last month told to root out corruption in state defence procurement.\n\nThe Izvestia newspaper said others had also been detained, though there was no official confirmation of that. The newspaper said Ivanov's properties were being searched. State television gave the case full coverage.\n\n\"Lets just say the investigation did not start yesterday, the day before yesterday or even a month ago,\" an unidentified Russia law enforcement source told the TASS state news agency. FSB military counter-intelligence was involved, TASS said.\n\nIt was not immediately clear why such a senior official with a close association with Shoigu would be targeted.\n\nRussian military bloggers have long accused top generals of corruption and incompetence, especially after the army's hurried withdrawal from parts of Ukraine after seriously over-extending itself during the first days of the invasion.\n\nWithin the Russian elite, there are a range of views on the war, which has had touched off the worst breakdown in relations between Russia and the West since the 1962 Cuban Missile Crisis.\n\nIvanov, who could not be reached as he was in detention, has long been linked to the ostentatious opulence which has characterised some sections of the post-Soviet Russian elite, including luxurious real estate and flashy parties.\n\nIn 2022, Russia's Anti-Corruption Foundation, headed by the late Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny, alleged that Ivanov and his family led a lavish lifestyle.\n\nIvanov, who was born in Moscow, graduated with a degree in mathematics from Moscow State University and completed a dissertation in the organisational models for the construction of nuclear power plants.\n\nHe rose through the ranks of Russia's state atomic energy sector and worked as an adviser to the energy minister before moving to become the deputy head of Moscow region's government under Shoigu, who was then governor.\n\nFrom 2013, Ivanov headed a defence ministry construction company which builds housing for soldiers and at high-security installations.\n\nForbes magazine listed Ivanov as one of the wealthiest men in Russia's security structures.", "source": {"uri": "economictimes.indiatimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Economic Times"}, "authors": [], 2016.\n\nAccording to the investigative outlet Dossier, Ivanov had gained Shoigu's favor for allegedly paying for media publications that bolster his public image.\n\n\"It is hard to find an official {"uri": "8096374908", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "08:56:26", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T08:56:26Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T08:56:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.bostonglobe.com/2024/04/25/nation/third-man-is-detained-major-bribery-case-that-involves-russias-deputy-defense-minister/", "title": "Third man is detained in a major bribery case that involves Russia's deputy defense minister - The Boston Globe", "body": "Moscow's court service said Fomin and Borodin contributed to Ivanov receiving a \"particularly large bribe\" -- an offense punishable by up to 15 years in prison.\n\nIvanov, 48, was sanctioned by both the United States and European Union in 2022 after Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine.\n\nAccording to a court statement, investigators told the judge that Ivanov conspired with third parties to receive a bribe in the form of unspecified property services \"during contracting and subcontracting work for the needs of the Ministry of Defense.\"\n\nIvanov's lawyer, Murad Musayev, told the state news agency Tass on Wednesday that his client is accused of \"taking a bribe in the form of free construction and repair work on supposedly his personal properties,\" and in turn providing \"assistance to companies that were contractors for the Defense Ministry.\"\n\nAnother lawyer, Denis Baluyev, was quoted by state news agency RIA Novosti as saying Wednesday that Ivanov maintains his innocence.\n\nAccording to the Defense Ministry's website, Ivanov was appointed in 2016 by a presidential decree. He oversaw property management, housing and medical support for the military, as well as construction projects.\n\nRIA Novosti quoted Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov as saying that Shoigu and President Vladimir Putin were informed of Ivanov's arrest, which comes as Moscow's war in Ukraine grinds through its third year.\n\nIndependent Russian news outlets reported Wednesday that the bribery charges were intended to hide more serious charges of treason and avoid scandal, citing two unidentified sources close to the Federal Security Service, or FSB.\n\nPeskov dismissed the suggestion and described the reports as speculation. \"There are a lot of rumors. We need to rely on official information,\" he told journalists.\n\nMusayev, Ivanov's lawyer, also denied any other charges, telling RIA Novosti Ivanov faced only bribery allegations.\n\nBefore his arrest, Ivanov was seen attending a meeting with Shoigu and other top military brass. The move against Ivanov came nearly a month after Putin called on the FSB to \"keep up a systemic anti-corruption effort\" and pay special attention to state defense procurement.\n\nRussian media reported that Ivanov oversaw some of the construction in Mariupol, a Ukrainian port city that was devastated by bombardment and occupied by Russian forces early in the war.\n\nZvezda, the official TV channel of the Russian military, reported in summer 2022 that the ministry was building an entire residential block in Mariupol and showed Ivanov inspecting construction sites and newly erected buildings.\n\nThat same year, the team of opposition leader Navalny alleged Ivanov and his family had been enjoying luxurious trips abroad, lavish parties and owned elite real estate. The activists also alleged that Ivanov's wife, Svetlana, divorced him in 2022 to avoid sanctions and continued living a lavish lifestyle.\n\nThe prosecution of high-level officials for corruption remains relatively rare in Russia.\n\nIn April 2023, former Deputy Culture Minister Olga Yarilova was arrested and charged with embezzling more than 200 million rubles ($2.2 million). Yarilova, who held her post from 2018 to 2022, is on trial and facing a possible seven-year jail term.", "source": {"uri": "bostonglobe.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Boston Globe"}, {"uri": "8096422897", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "09:27:48", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T09:27:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T09:24:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.globalsecurity.org/wmd/library/news/russia/2024/04/russia-240423-rferl01.htm", "title": "Russian Deputy Defense Minister Detained On Suspicion Of Corruption", "body": "Russian law enforcement officials have detained Deputy Defense Minister Timur Ivanov on suspicion of taking a bribe, the Investigative Committee said on April 23.\n\nThe committee announced the arrest of Ivanov on Telegram but provided no further details of the accusations against him, saying only that he is suspected of taking an especially large bribe -- a criminal offense punishable by up to 15 years in prison.\n\nThe 49-year-old was the subject of an investigation published in December 2022 by Aleksei Navalny's Anti-Corruption Foundation (FBK).\n\nIt said that Ivanov oversaw and profited from construction projects in the Ukrainian city of Mariupol, which was heavily bombarded and occupied by Russian forces in the first months of Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine.\n\nThe investigation showed that Ivanov and his wife, Svetlana, spent more than 1 million euros ($1.07 million) on vacations, renting villas and yachts, jewelry, and clothes. It also showed that the personal bills of Ivanov's wife were paid by a company engaged in the restoration of Mariupol.\n\nAccording to the FBK, which has been banned in Russia for alleged extremism, the minister divorced his wife to allow her to bypass EU sanctions.\n\n\"Today is a good day,\" said Maria Pevchikh, the head of investigations at the foundation, in a post on X, formerly Twitter.\n\n\"The person involved in our investigation was detained on suspicion of bribery. We talked about the glamorous and luxurious life of Deputy Defense Minister Timur Ivanov back at the end of 2022.\"\n\nIvanov was appointed deputy defense minister by presidential decree in May 2016.\n\nKremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said a report on Ivanov's detention had been presented to President Vladimir Putin, according to Russian news agencies.\n\nDefense Minister Sergei Shoigu had been informed in advance of his detention, he said.\n\nIvanov's duties included overseeing housing for troops and the construction and overhaul of ministry facilities. Ivanov has been designated for sanctions by United States, the European Union, Britain, and Canada.\n\nForbes magazine listed Ivanov as one of the wealthiest men in Russia's security structures.\n\nCopyright (c) 2024. {"uri": "8094583529", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "09:26:39", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T09:26:39Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T09:26:30Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/russian-deputy-defence-minister-detained-232434899.html", "title": "Russian deputy defence minister Timur Ivanov accused of taking bribes", "body": "A Russian deputy defence minister has been accused of taking bribes and remanded in custody by a court in Moscow.\n\nTimur Ivanov, who denies the charges, is accused of accepting bribes \"on a particularly large scale\".\n\nAppointed to the defence ministry in 2016, Mr Ivanov, 47, has been responsible for Russia's military infrastructure projects.\n\nActivists have long criticised the levels of alleged corruption in Russia.\n\nHowever, such high profile cases have been rare since the start of Russia's full-scale invasion of Ukraine in 2022.\n\nMr Ivanov is considered an ally of Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu and has worked with him for many years. He was previously deputy prime minister of the Moscow region, where Mr Shoigu briefly served as governor.\n\nIn 2022, the Anti-Corruption Foundation (ACF), the group founded by late opposition leader Alexei Navalny, accused Mr Ivanov of participating in \"corruption schemes during construction in the territories of Ukraine occupied by Russia\".\n\nIn particular, it said he had profited from construction projects in the Ukrainian port city of Mariupol, much of which was destroyed by Russian bombing in the months following the full-scale invasion of Ukraine.\n\nBasmanny district court in Moscow remanded him in jail for two months on charges of entering into a criminal conspiracy with third parties in his role of supervising the construction and overhaul of defence ministry facilities.\n\nIf found guilty he could face up to 15 years in jail. A second man, Sergei Borodin, who was described as a friend of the Mr Ivanov, also appeared in court on Moscow on similar charges.\n\nMr Ivanov denied the allegations made against him by Russia's Investigative Committee. The section of Russia's criminal code under which Mr Ivanov was detained - Part 6 of article 290 - applies when a suspected bribe exceeds one million roubles (\u00a38,620; $10,700).\n\nMr Ivanov's arrest marks a rare move against a member of Russia's governing elite, many of whom are believed to have used their positions to amass vast personal fortunes.\n\nSome Russian commentators have said the arrest will be a blow to Mr Shoigu. \"If he can't manage it, he will be next to fall. This person is 100% his man,\" one anonymous source told a popular military Telegram channel.\n\nKremlin spokesperson Dmitry Peskov told reporters that President Vladimir Putin had been notified of the detention in advance.\n\nMr Ivanov has been sanctioned by the US and UK and is the subject of a travel ban and asset freeze imposed by the European Union, which describes him as being \"tenth in the overall hierarchy of the Russian military leadership\".", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8096766574", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-25", "time": "12:52:47", "dateTime": "2024-04-25T12:52:47Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-25T12:52:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://www.nbcnews.com/news/world/russia-corruption-scandal-deputy-defense-minister-timur-ivanov-fomin-rcna149298", "title": "Construction boss accused of bribing Russian minister as scandal widens", "body": "Some analysts see the affair as a sign of tensions in the elite as Putin prepares to name a new government.Natalia Kolesnikova / AFP via Getty Images\n\nA third man has been detained in a bribery investigation centering on Deputy Russian Defense Minister Timur Ivanov, the Moscow court service said on Thursday.\n\nThe widening scandal is the worst to hit the defense ministry since the start of the war in Ukraine, and has gripped the political and media establishment in the run-up to a government reshuffle that President Vladimir Putin is expected to announce next month.\n\nThe court service said Alexander Fomin, the co-founder of a construction company called Olimpsitistroy, was suspected of paying bribes to Ivanov, who was detained on Tuesday, and Sergei Borodin, a close associate of Ivanov who is also in custody.\n\nThe court service said Fomin, \"being in a relationship of trust with Ivanov\", was suspected of providing free services to him, Borodin and others.\n\n\"Also, Fomin and other persons, acting as an organized group, contributed to Ivanov's receipt of a particularly large bribe in the form of the illegal provision of property-related services to him,\" it said.\n\nBusiness newspaper Kommersant said investigators suspected Ivanov of receiving kickbacks from Fomin in return for helping his company win contracts worth hundreds of millions of dollars.\n\nIvanov, who maintains his innocence, was arrested at work on Tuesday by the Federal Security Service, the main successor to the Soviet-era KGB. He faces 15 years in jail if convicted.\n\nThere was no immediate comment from Fomin and Borodin on the matter.\n\nIvanov was a close ally of Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu, who risks being damaged by the scandal. State news agency TASS quoted a source as saying that Shoigu had fired Ivanov since his arrest. TASS said investigators had seized all the bank accounts and property of Ivanov and his family.\n\nSome analysts see the affair as an attempt to weaken Shoigu and a sign of tensions and rivalries in the elite as Putin prepares to name a new government next month after being re-elected in March for another six-year term.\n\nShoigu, however, is expected to keep his job. Under his direction, Russian forces have regrouped and regained the initiative in Ukraine and have recorded a series of gains in the past two months.\n\nIvanov, who has served as deputy minister since 2016, was in charge of property management, housing, construction and mortgages at the defense ministry, whose spending has spiraled since the war began.\n\nHe had long been the subject of journalistic investigations.\n\nRussia's Anti-Corruption Foundation, headed by late opposition leader Alexei Navalny, had alleged that Ivanov and his family lived a life of luxury including yachts, helicopters, visits to the French Riviera, purchases of diamonds and a 19th century mansion in Moscow.\n\nForbes magazine listed Ivanov as one of the wealthiest men in Russia's security structures. {"uri": "8094400353", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "07:35:21", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T07:35:21Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T07:34:49Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7529411911964417, "url": "https://arynews.tv/russia-detains-deputy-defence-minister-for-corruption/", "title": "Russia detains deputy defence minister for corruption", "body": "MOSCOW: Security services of Russia detained one of Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu's deputies on suspicion of taking major bribes, the highest-profile corruption case since President Vladimir Putin sent troops into Ukraine in February 2022.\n\nDeputy Defence Minister Timur Ivanov was detained on Tuesday, according to a brief 22-word statement by Russia's investigative committee. The statute that the investigators cited for his detention is for accepting bribes \"on a particularly large scale\".\n\nHe faces 15 years in jail if convicted.\n\nThe sudden arrest of an ally of Shoigu, who Putin tasked with fighting the war in Ukraine, triggered speculation about a battle within the elite and of a public crackdown on the corruption which has plagued Russia's post-Soviet armed forces.\n\nThe Kremlin said Putin had been informed, and added that Shoigu had also been told. Ivanov was present earlier on Tuesday at a meeting of top defence officials chaired by Shoigu.\n\nIvanov, who has served as deputy minister since 2016, was in charge of property management, housing, construction and mortgages at the defence ministry. The defence ministry has made no comment.\n\nRussia's Kommersant newspaper said that Ivanov, 48, was arrested by the Federal Security Service (FSB), the successor to the Soviet-era KGB which Putin last month told to root out corruption in state defence procurement.\n\nThe Izvestia newspaper said others had also been detained, though there was no official confirmation of that. The newspaper said Ivanov's properties were being searched. State television gave the case full coverage.\n\n\"Lets just say the investigation did not start yesterday, the day before yesterday or even a month ago,\" an unidentified Russia law enforcement source told the TASS state news agency. FSB military counter-intelligence was involved, TASS said.\n\nIt was not immediately clear why such a senior official with a close association with Shoigu would be targeted.\n\nRussian military bloggers have long accused top generals of corruption and incompetence, especially after the army's hurried withdrawal from parts of Ukraine after seriously over-extending itself during the first days of the invasion.\n\nWithin the Russian elite, there are a range of views on the war, which has had touched off the worst breakdown in relations between Russia and the West since the 1962 Cuban Missile Crisis.\n\nIvanov, who could not be reached as he was in detention, has long been linked to the ostentatious opulence which has characterised some sections of the post-Soviet Russian elite, including luxurious real estate and flashy parties.\n\nIn 2022, Russia's Anti-Corruption Foundation, headed by the late Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny, alleged that Ivanov and his family led a lavish lifestyle.\n\nIvanov, who was born in Moscow, graduated with a degree in mathematics from Moscow State University and completed a dissertation in the organisational models for the construction of nuclear power plants.\n\nHe rose through the ranks of Russia's state atomic energy sector and worked as an adviser to the energy minister before moving to become the deputy head of Moscow region's government under Shoigu, who was then governor.\n\nFrom 2013, Ivanov headed a defence ministry construction company which builds housing for soldiers and at high-security installations.\n\nForbes magazine listed Ivanov as one of the wealthiest men in Russia's security structures.", "source": {"uri": "arynews.tv", "dataType": "news", "title": "ARY NEWS"}, "authors": [{"uri": He faces 15 years in prison if convicted.\n\nIvanov will be held under a detention order for two months, according to the TASS news agency, which said a man named Sergei Borodin has also been taken into custody on suspicion of complicity in receiving bribes by Ivanov.\n\nThe 48-year-old deputy defence minister oversaw military construction and repairs and is accused of taking part in a {"uri": "8094771014", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "11:16:35", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T11:16:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T11:16:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://english.pravda.ru/russia/159465-timur-ivanov-shoigu/", "title": "'Shoigu's man' Timur Ivanov arrested for what is believed to be large bribery case", "body": "Timur Ivanov, Russian Deputy Defence Minister, was arrested on April 23 in the case of bribery. He will remain in custody before June 2024.\n\nA Moscow court sent Deputy Defence Minister Timur Ivanov to a pre-trial detention centre. He was arrested for two months, until June 23. Ivanov was charged under Part 6 of Art. 290 of the Criminal Code (receiving a bribe on an especially large scale).\n\nAccording to investigators, Ivanov entered into a \"criminal conspiracy with third parties to commit a crime and received a large bribe in the form of property services provided during contracting and subcontracting works for the needs of the Defence Ministry.\"\n\nSecurity forces are conducting dozens of searches in several Russian regions in relation to the case of Deputy Defence Minister Timur Ivanov, RBC reports. It was ai that FSB officers were working in the Krasnodar and Stavropol territories of Southern Russia.\n\nTimur Ivanov was detained on Tuesday at 17:00 in his office. The materials of Ivanov's criminal case are related to his official duties. He is suspected of receiving a bribe on an especially large scale (Part 6 of Article 290 of the Criminal Code). He faces up to 15 years in prison under this article.\n\nTimur Ivanov did not plead guilty at court.\n\nThe materials of the case against Ivanov are based on the testimony of witnesses and the results of operational activities. The official has been under criminal intelligence analysis for a long time, a source told TASS. Operational support of the criminal case is carried out by the military counterintelligence of the FSB.\n\nIvanov is \"a man of Shoigu's.\" He \"had problems\" and \"there were questions to him\". His detention may be related to Shoigu's possible departure from the ministry, Forbes said with reference to a source at the Defence Ministry. There is no official confirmation to such reports.\n\nDeputy Defense Minister Ivanov is allegedly suspected of treason, whereas his bribery case appears to be just art of the charges that could be exposed to the public, sources of \"Important Stories\" said.\n\nHowever, Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov said that one should believe official information only.\n\n\"There are a lot of different rumours around this whole thing, one needs to rely on official information, all these discussions are speculations around this case,\" Peskov said.\n\nThree more people were detained in this case, previously all of them were employees of the Defence Ministry or government agencies.\n\nInvestigative measures are being carried out at Ivanov's dacha in Dagestan.\n\nSeveral people who were considered to be involved in the transfer of money through a \"complex chain of intermediaries,\" were also arrested, Izvestia said.\n\nPresident Vladimir Putin knew in advance about Ivanov's detention, Kremlin's official spokesman Dmitry Peskov said. Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu was also informed about Ivanov's arrest. It is worthy of note that on the day of his arrest, Timur Ivanov was present at the meeting of the board of the Ministry of Defence led by Sergei Shoigu.", "source": {"uri": "english.pravda.ru", {"uri": "2024-04-333813771", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "11:35:06", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T11:35:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T11:28:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://uk.news.yahoo.com/russian-deputy-defence-minister-held-112850601.html", "title": "Russian deputy defence minister held over bribery accusations", "body": "A Russian deputy defence minister exposed in an investigation by late opposition leader Alexei Navalny's team was remanded in custody Wednesday on suspicion of taking large bribes.\n\nThe arrest of Timur Ivanov, a long-time ally of Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu, is the most dramatic corruption case in Russia in recent years. It comes as spending on the military has ballooned amid its offensive on Ukraine.\n\nIvanov, 48, oversaw construction and procurement for the armed forces, and was linked to Russia's high-profile rebuilding of the Ukrainian city of Mariupol, occupied by Moscow's forces.\n\n\"The deputy defence minister of the Russian Federation was sent to a pre-trial detention centre,\" the press service for Moscow courthouses said in a statement on social media.\n\nHe faces up to 15 years in prison for bribe-taking \"on a particularly large scale\", it added.\n\nIvanov denies the charges, his lawyer told the state-run TASS news agency.\n\nSeveral independent Russian media outlets have alleged that Ivanov and his family acquired vast wealth through kick-backs on contracts he agreed at the ministry.\n\n- Lavish lifestyle -\n\nIn December 2022, Navalny's team said they had obtained thousands of leaked emails from Ivanov's wife, Svetlana Maniovich, that showed a lavish lifestyle well beyond what his official salary could cover.\n\nThey said she had spent hundreds of thousands of euros on luxury cars, jewellery, clothes, parties, and renting premium property and yachts in the south of France.\n\nSome of the transactions were routed through third parties, including defence ministry contractors, they alleged.\n\nThe Kremlin said President Vladimir Putin was in \"constant\" contact with Shoigu but refused to comment directly on Ivanov's arrest.\n\n\"There will be an investigation,\" spokesman Dmitry Peskov said, cautioning against \"speculation\".\n\nIn court on Wednesday, Ivanov, 48, stood in a glass dock for defendants in military uniform.\n\nThe court said investigators believe he was part of a \"criminal conspiracy\" to take a \"bribe on a particularly large scale in the form of property services, during the course of contracting and subcontracting work for the defence ministry.\"\n\nIt did not provide further details.\n\nThe judge sent him to pre-trial detention until at least June 23. He will be held at the notorious Lefortovo jail in Moscow, TASS reported.\n\n- 'Shoigu's deputy' -\n\nCampaigners, including Navalny, have long argued that corruption is endemic in Putin's Russia.\n\nArrests of high-profile government figures are rare, usually the result of political infighting, analysts say.\n\nActivists say the vast sums being poured into the Ukraine offensive has given officials new opportunities to enrich themselves through secretive procurement deals.\n\nRussian military bloggers, who have long criticised Shoigu's handling of the offensive, quickly linked Ivanov to the defence minister on social media.\n\nIn a post criticising Ivanov, Wagner-linked Telegram channel Grey Zone repeatedly referred to him as \"Shoigu's Deputy\".\n\n\"He, like Shoigu, comes from the family clan,\" it said.\n\nFormer Wagner boss Yevgeny Prigozhin had accused Shoigu and other defence ministry officials of corruption and incompetence before his mysterious death last year.\n\nThe defence ministry has not commented on Ivanov's arrest.\n\nJust hours before investigators announced they had arrested Ivanov on Tuesday he had appeared in video footage published by the {"uri": "8094388328", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "07:28:35", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T07:28:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T07:26:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7490196228027344, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-13343941/Russia-detains-deputy-defence-minister-Shoigu-corruption.html", "title": "Russia detains deputy of defence minister Shoigu for corruption", "body": "Russia's FSB detains deputy defence minister\n\n*\n\nIvanov is suspected of major bribe taking\n\n*\n\nIvanov is an ally of Defence Minister Shoigu\n\nBy Guy Faulconbridge, Lidia Kelly\n\nMOSCOW, April 24 (Reuters) - Russian security services detained one of Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu's deputies on suspicion of taking major bribes, the highest-profile corruption case since President Vladimir Putin sent troops into Ukraine in February 2022.\n\nDeputy Defence Minister Timur Ivanov was detained on Tuesday, according to a brief 22-word statement by Russia's investigative committee. The statute that the investigators cited for his detention is for accepting bribes \"on a particularly large scale\".\n\nHe faces 15 years in jail if convicted.\n\nThe sudden arrest of an ally of Shoigu, who Putin tasked with fighting the war in Ukraine, triggered speculation about a battle within the elite and of a public crackdown on the corruption which has plagued Russia's post-Soviet armed forces.\n\nThe Kremlin said Putin had been informed, and added that Shoigu had also been told. Ivanov was present earlier on Tuesday at a meeting of top defence officials chaired by Shoigu.\n\nIvanov, who has served as deputy minister since 2016, was in charge of property management, housing, construction and mortgages at the defence ministry. The defence ministry has made no comment.\n\nRussia's Kommersant newspaper said that Ivanov, 48, was arrested by the Federal Security Service (FSB), the successor to the Soviet-era KGB which Putin last month told to root out corruption in state defence procurement.\n\nThe Izvestia newspaper said others had also been detained, though there was no official confirmation of that. The newspaper said Ivanov's properties were being searched. State television gave the case full coverage.\n\n\"Lets just say the investigation did not start yesterday, the day before yesterday or even a month ago,\" an unidentified Russia law enforcement source told the TASS state news agency. FSB military counter-intelligence was involved, TASS said.\n\nIt was not immediately clear why such a senior official with a close association with Shoigu would be targeted.\n\nRussian military bloggers have long accused top generals of corruption and incompetence, especially after the army's hurried withdrawal from parts of Ukraine after seriously over-extending itself during the first days of the invasion.\n\nWithin the Russian elite, there are a range of views on the war, which has had touched off the worst breakdown in relations between Russia and the West since the 1962 Cuban Missile Crisis.\n\nIvanov, who could not be reached as he was in detention, has long been linked to the ostentatious opulence which has characterised some sections of the post-Soviet Russian elite, including luxurious real estate and flashy parties.\n\nIn 2022, Russia's Anti-Corruption Foundation, headed by the late Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny, alleged that Ivanov and his family led a lavish lifestyle.\n\nIvanov, who was born in Moscow, graduated with a degree in mathematics from Moscow State University and completed a dissertation in the organisational models for the construction of nuclear power plants.\n\nHe rose through the ranks of Russia's state atomic energy sector and worked as an adviser to the energy minister before moving to become the deputy head of Moscow region's government under Shoigu, who was then governor.\n\nFrom 2013, Ivanov headed a defence ministry construction company which builds housing for soldiers and at high-security installations.\n\nForbes magazine listed Ivanov as one of the wealthiest men in Russia's security structures. (Reporting by Reuters; Writing by Guy Faulconbridge and Lidia Kelly; Editing by Daniel Wallis, Gerry Doyle and Ros Russell)", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily {"uri": "8094894357", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "12:28:34", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T12:28:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T12:28:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7450980544090271, "url": "https://www.arabtimesonline.com/news/top-russian-military-official-appears-in-court-on-bribery-charges/", "title": "Top Russian military official appears in court on bribery charges", "body": "MOSCOW, April 24, (AP): A top Russian military official arrested on suspicion of accepting a bribe was sent to pre-trial detention Wednesday after appearing before a court in central Moscow, court officials said in a statement.\n\nTimur Ivanov, 48, one of Russia's 12 deputy defense ministers, was arrested Tuesday evening, Russia's Investigative Committee said in a statement. It gave no further information, apart from specifying that Ivanov is suspected of taking an especially large bribe - a criminal offense punishable by up to 15 years in prison.\n\nAccording to a statement from the court, investigators told Moscow's Basmany court Wednesday that Ivanov had conspired with third parties to receive a bribe in the form of unspecified property services \"during contracting and subcontracting work for the needs of the Ministry of Defense.\"\n\nAn acquaintance of Ivanov's, identified as Sergei Borodin, was also arrested and ordered into pre-trial detention on the same charges, court officials said in a separate statement. Both men are to remain in custody until at least June 23.\n\nAccording to the defense ministry's website, Ivanov was appointed to the post in 2016 by a presidential decree. He oversaw property management, housing and medical support for the military, construction and reconstruction of facilities.\n\nRussia's state news agency RIA Novosti quoted Kremlin spokesman Dmitry Peskov as saying that both President Vladimir Putin and Defense Minister Sergei Shoigu were informed about Ivanov's arrest, which comes as Moscow's war in Ukraine continues into its third year.\n\nPeskov also dismissed reports in the Russian media Wednesday that the corruption allegations against Ivanov were intended to obscure additional allegations of high treason.\n\nIndependent Russian news outlet reported that the bribery charges were intended to hide more serious charges and avoid public scandal, citing two unnamed sources close to Russia's Federal Security Services.", {"uri": "8094388326", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "07:28:11", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T07:28:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T07:26:23Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/reuters/article-13343943/Russia-detains-deputy-defense-minister-Shoigu-corruption.html", "title": "Russia detains deputy of defense minister Shoigu for corruption", "body": "Russia's FSB detains deputy defense minister\n\n*\n\nIvanov is suspected of major bribe taking\n\n*\n\nIvanov is an ally of Defence Minister Shoigu\n\nBy Guy Faulconbridge, Lidia Kelly\n\nMOSCOW, April 24 (Reuters) - Russian security services detained one of Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu's deputies on suspicion of taking major bribes, the highest-profile corruption case since President Vladimir Putin sent troops into Ukraine in February 2022.\n\nDeputy Defence Minister Timur Ivanov was detained on Tuesday, according to a brief 22-word statement by Russia's investigative committee. The statute that the investigators cited for his detention is for accepting bribes \"on a particularly large scale.\"\n\nHe faces 15 years in jail if convicted.\n\nThe sudden arrest of an ally of Shoigu, who Putin tasked with fighting the war in Ukraine, triggered speculation about a battle within the elite and of a public crackdown on the corruption which has plagued Russia's post-Soviet armed forces.\n\nThe Kremlin said Putin had been informed, and added that Shoigu had also been told. Ivanov was present earlier on Tuesday at a meeting of top defense officials chaired by Shoigu.\n\nIvanov, who has served as deputy minister since 2016, was in charge of property management, housing, construction and mortgages at the defense ministry. The defense ministry has made no comment.\n\nRussia's Kommersant newspaper said that Ivanov, 48, was arrested by the Federal Security Service (FSB), the successor to the Soviet-era KGB which Putin last month told to root out corruption in state defense procurement.\n\nThe Izvestia newspaper said others had also been detained, though there was no official confirmation of that. The newspaper said Ivanov's properties were being searched. State television gave the case full coverage.\n\n\"Lets just say the investigation did not start yesterday, the day before yesterday or even a month ago,\" an unidentified Russia law enforcement source told the TASS state news agency. FSB military counter-intelligence was involved, TASS said.\n\nIt was not immediately clear why such a senior official with a close association with Shoigu would be targeted.\n\nRussian military bloggers have long accused top generals of corruption and incompetence, especially after the army's hurried withdrawal from parts of Ukraine after seriously over-extending itself during the first days of the invasion.\n\nWithin the Russian elite, there are a range of views on the war, which has had touched off the worst breakdown in relations between Russia and the West since the 1962 Cuban Missile Crisis.\n\nIvanov, who could not be reached as he was in detention, has long been linked to the ostentatious opulence which has characterized some sections of the post-Soviet Russian elite, including luxurious real estate and flashy parties.\n\nIn 2022, Russia's Anti-Corruption Foundation, headed by the late Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny, alleged that Ivanov and his family led a lavish lifestyle.\n\nIvanov, who was born in Moscow, graduated with a degree in mathematics from Moscow State University and completed a dissertation in the organizational models for the construction of nuclear power plants.\n\nHe rose through the ranks of Russia's state atomic energy sector and worked as an adviser to the energy minister before moving to become the deputy head of Moscow region's government under Shoigu, who was then governor.\n\nFrom 2013, Ivanov headed a defense ministry construction company which builds housing for soldiers and at high-security installations.\n\nForbes magazine listed Ivanov as one of the wealthiest men in Russia's security structures. He faces 15 years in prison if convicted.\n\nIvanov will be held under a detention order for two months, according to the TASS news agency, which said a man named Sergei Borodin has also been taken into custody on suspicion of complicity in receiving bribes by Ivanov.\n\nThe 48-year-old deputy defence minister oversaw military construction and repairs and is accused of taking part in a {"uri": "8094687619", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "10:27:09", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T10:27:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T10:26:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://theprint.in/world/russia-detains-ally-of-defence-minister-shoigu-for-corruption/2054598/", "title": "Russia detains ally of Defence Minister Shoigu for corruption", "body": "Moscow's Basmanny District Court ordered Ivanov be kept in custody until June 23. Ivanov, 48, dressed in his uniform, was shown standing in a glass cage in court, frowning slightly, footage released by the court service showed.\n\n\"The investigation believes that Ivanov entered into a criminal conspiracy with third parties, teamed up with them in advance to commit an organised crime by an organised group,\" the court service said.\n\nThe conspiracy was to receive \"property and services on a particularly large scale during contract and sub-contract work for the ministry of defence,\" the court service said.\n\nRussian media said he denied being guilty. He faces 15 years in jail if convicted. State media gave the case full coverage.\n\nThe sudden arrest of an ally of Shoigu, who Putin tasked with fighting the war in Ukraine, triggered speculation about a battle within the elite and of a public crackdown on the corruption which has plagued Russia's post-Soviet armed forces.\n\nSome Russian bloggers, who have long accused senior generals of incompetence, rejoiced at the apparent fall of a top military official long linked to the ostentatious opulence which Putin has made clear he does not want to see displayed in wartime.\n\nSome said the arrest could be a public lesson for the elite, though others said it was a blow for Shoigu, a close Putin ally and one of Russia's most powerful men.\n\nThe Kremlin said Putin had been informed, and added that Shoigu had also been told. The defence ministry made no comment. A close friend of Ivanov's, Sergei Borodin, was also charged with conspiring to take bribes.\n\nIvanov, who has served as deputy minister since 2016, was in charge of property management, housing, construction and mortgages at the defence ministry - whose spending has spiralled since the start of the war.\n\n\"Lets just say the investigation did not start yesterday, the day before yesterday or even a month ago,\" an unidentified Russian law enforcement source told the TASS state news agency. FSB military counter-intelligence was involved, TASS said.\n\nIvanov had long been the subject of journalistic investigations which alleged he and his family lived a lavish lifestyle complete with visits to Europe's most expensive boutiques and an array of deluxe real estate.\n\nIn 2022, Russia's Anti-Corruption Foundation, headed by the late Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny, investigated Ivanov.\n\nIt alleged that he and his family lived a life of luxury including yachts, helicopters, visits to French Riviera, purchases of diamonds and even a 19th Century mansion on one of Moscow's most elegant streets.\n\nForbes magazine listed Ivanov as one of the wealthiest men in Russia's security structures. Other investigations alleged corruption in Russia's reconstruction of Mariupol, the Ukrainian city on the Sea of Azov that is controlled by Russian forces.\n\nIvanov was unable to comment as he was in detention. Putin last month ordered the FSB to root out corruption in state defence procurement.\n\nIvanov, who graduated with a degree in mathematics from Moscow State University, rose through the ranks of Russia's state atomic energy sector before moving to become the deputy head of Moscow region's government under Shoigu, who was then governor.\n\nSome Russian military bloggers have long accused top generals of corruption, especially after the army's hurried withdrawal from parts of Ukraine after over-extending itself during the first days of the invasion.\n\n\"It is clear that this is a tectonic shift,\" said Yuri Podolyaka, one of the most popular pro-Russian military bloggers. \"And this is not about Ivanov... {"uri": "8095681433", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "22:09:46", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T22:09:46Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T22:09:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7372549176216125, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/world-news/poisonous-feud-erupts-inside-putins-32664953", "title": "Feud erupts in Putin's regime as he parades 'traitor' defence minister", "body": "A poisonous feud has opened inside the Putin war-mongering regime with the arrest of the dictator's deputy defence minister on suspicion of corruption and possibly treason.\n\nTimur Ivanov, 48, is the closest aide to Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu, in charge of the war against Ukraine. The wealthy minister - fond of glamorous women and lavish parties - appeared in the dock today in military fatigues accused of taking a bribe.\n\nYet one news outlet today sensationally claimed Vladimir Putin has been convinced by unknown briefings that Ivanov has committed treason - and this is the real reason for his detention.\n\n\"A bribe is for the public. So far they don't want to talk publicly about treason - it's a big scandal, after all [he is] the Deputy Minister of Defence,\" a source told Important Stories news outlet.\n\nIvanov's wife Svetlana Maniovich\n\n\"No one would have detained him for corruption. Everyone there [in the Kremlin] knew about this for a long time,\" said a security source. Putin gave the command after he managed to convince us that we were talking about treason.\"\n\nAfter appearing in court, Ivanov was then humiliatingly ordered to change into civilian clothes before being taken away for two months of pre-trial detention from Basmanny district court in Moscow pending an FSB secret service probe into alleged corruption.\n\nHe was seen being held and pushed by the neck by an FSB officer. An alleged accomplice, Sergei Borodin, was also detained. His court appearance was shown widely by the state media suggesting a show trial is on the way, with a potential jail sentence of 15 years.\n\nIvanov, who holds a rank equivalent to an army general and was handcuffed in his office at the Defence Ministry, has now been slammed in grim Lefortovo jail in Moscow.\n\nVladimir Putin, Russian Defence Ministery Sergei Shoigu and Deputy Minister of Defence Timur Ivanov\n\nThe colourful Ivanov is known as one of Putin's wealthiest security officials and the dictator along with Shoigu was informed in advance that he was to be held\n\nThe arrest was seen as evidence of warring clans vying for power as Putin shuffles his regime following his latest inauguration next month.\n\nIvanov's humiliation could spell bad news for Shoigu who loses his key sidekick in the midst of war. The detained deputy minister had been nicknamed \"Shoigu's wallet\".\n\nBut the detained minister is also close to Putin's own mouthpiece Dmitry Peskov, who is also deputy head of the Kremlin administration. At one event Peskov - Putin's official spokesman - wore a bear's outfit as he partied alongside Ivanov.\n\nThe Russian Deputy Defence Minister attending a meeting in Moscow on April 23\n\nIvanov has ridden numerous past claims of corruption as he ran the military's infrastructure budget and rebuilt the blitzed and invaded Ukrainian city of Mariupol.\n\nAnd corruption is endemic in the Putin regime, so analysts are searching to explain 'why him and why now'. The Important Stories security-linked source said: \"Now they are deciding what to do with him [Ivanov].\n\n\"Either they will jail him for a bribe and 'finish him off' in the [war] zone, or reclassify the charge as treason.\" Ivanov's stepson, whom he shared skiing trips with, is reportedly educated in Britain - despite the war against Ukraine.\n\nAnd have claimed a divorce seven months after the war started from his wife socialite ex-TV star Svetlana Zakharova [Maniovich] - fond of posing semi-nude in the Maldives - was a \"sham\" to protect from Western sanctions as she carried on a lavish life in Britain, France and other European countries.\n\nIvanov has played a key role in the destruction of Ukraine\n\nThe couple boasted 11 vehicles including Mercedes-Benz and Bentley cars, while Ivanov's daughter has an apartment in Mexico. Svetlana, 52, rents expensive villas in St Tropez and prefers to travel by Rolls-Royce, according to an expose by 'murdered' Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny's team last year.\n\n\"We could not find any evidence of the reality of the breakup between [Svetlana] and Ivanov,\" said the team at the time. She \"radiates richness - diamonds, furs, Rolls Royces, she has it all and more.\n\n\"In summer you can find her in St Tropez where she rents a villa for \u20ac150k/month, or on a yacht in Naples... She loves shopping. Sadly, Moscow doesn't satisfy her fashion needs, so she has to travel to Paris.\n\n\"She gets personal appointments at one of the most expensive and discrete fine jewellery stores. This is where she gets \u20ac150K earrings and \u20ac104K rings made for her.\"\n\nShe and Ivanov the couple share two daughters - Praskovya, born in 2018, and Darya, born in 2010. Baza media outlet today reported that Svetlana was \"of interest to the investigation\" into alleged Ivanov corruption.\n\nThere are even unconfirmed claims she had been arrested - even though the couple are not believed to be together currently.\n\nMore recently rumours have surfaced that the womanising Ivanov is now romantically linked to with Shoigu's close former advisor Maria Kitaeva, another ex-TV presenter, born in Belgium and close to Putin.\n\nIn fact, Ivanov had taken Kitaeva who was married to his fellow deputy defence minister, Ukrainian-born Yuri Sadovenko. As the new relationship was sealed she bought Ivanov monogrammed pyjamas with the letters MK and TI. She had previously hosted the annual Direct Line with Putin TV question and answer extravaganza.\n\nIvanov has been sanctioned by the UK, the US, Canada, Australia, Japan, Ukraine, Switzerland, and New Zealand since 2022 over Putin's invasion. The FSB has been probing Ivanov for five years, say reports. {"uri": "8094894687", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "12:28:45", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T12:28:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T12:28:32Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/russian-deputy-defence-minister-held-over-bribery-accusations/article_05384e10-7058-5387-ae31-3af3566d36fa.html", "title": "Russian deputy defence minister held over bribery accusations", "body": "A Russian deputy defence minister exposed in an investigation by late opposition leader Alexei Navalny's team was remanded in custody Wednesday on suspicion of taking large bribes.\n\nThe arrest of Timur Ivanov, a long-time ally of Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu, is the most dramatic corruption case in Russia in recent years. It comes as spending on the military has ballooned amid its offensive on Ukraine.\n\nIvanov, 48, oversaw construction and procurement for the armed forces, and was linked to Russia's high-profile rebuilding of the Ukrainian city of Mariupol, occupied by Moscow's forces.\n\n\"The deputy defence minister of the Russian Federation was sent to a pre-trial detention centre,\" the press service for Moscow courthouses said in a statement on social media.\n\nHe faces up to 15 years in prison for bribe-taking \"on a particularly large scale\", it added.\n\nIvanov denies the charges, his lawyer told the state-run TASS news agency.\n\nSeveral independent Russian media outlets have alleged that Ivanov and his family acquired vast wealth through kick-backs on contracts he agreed at the ministry.\n\n- Lavish lifestyle -\n\nIn December 2022, Navalny's team said they had obtained thousands of leaked emails from Ivanov's wife, Svetlana Maniovich, that showed a lavish lifestyle well beyond what his official salary could cover.\n\nThey said she had spent hundreds of thousands of euros on luxury cars, jewellery, clothes, parties, and renting premium property and yachts in the south of France.\n\nSome of the transactions were routed through third parties, including defence ministry contractors, they alleged.\n\nThe Kremlin said President Vladimir Putin was in \"constant\" contact with Shoigu but refused to comment directly on Ivanov's arrest.\n\n\"There will be an investigation,\" spokesman Dmitry Peskov said, cautioning against \"speculation\".\n\nIn court on Wednesday, Ivanov, 48, stood in a glass dock for defendants in military uniform.\n\nMore from this section Korda captures Chevron crown for second major, LPGA record fifth straight win Talks on global plastic treaty begin in Canada Biden hammers Trump on abortion in Florida\n\nThe court said investigators believe he was part of a \"criminal conspiracy\" to take a \"bribe on a particularly large scale in the form of property services, during the course of contracting and subcontracting work for the defence ministry.\"\n\nIt did not provide further details.\n\nThe judge sent him to pre-trial detention until at least June 23. He will be held at the notorious Lefortovo jail in Moscow, TASS reported.\n\n- 'Shoigu's deputy' -\n\nCampaigners, including Navalny, have long argued that corruption is endemic in Putin's Russia.\n\nArrests of high-profile government figures are rare, usually the result of political infighting, analysts say.\n\nActivists say the vast sums being poured into the Ukraine offensive has given officials new opportunities to enrich themselves through secretive procurement deals.\n\nRussian military bloggers, who have long criticised Shoigu's handling of the offensive, quickly linked Ivanov to the defence minister on social media.\n\nIn a post criticising Ivanov, Wagner-linked Telegram channel Grey Zone repeatedly referred to him as \"Shoigu's Deputy\".\n\n\"He, like Shoigu, comes from the family clan,\" it said.\n\nFormer Wagner boss Yevgeny Prigozhin had accused Shoigu and other defence ministry officials of corruption and incompetence before his mysterious death last year.\n\nThe defence ministry has not commented on Ivanov's arrest.\n\nJust hours before investigators announced they had arrested Ivanov on Tuesday he had appeared in video footage published by the ministry in which Shoigu addressed top military brass about the state of the Ukraine offensive.\n\nbur/jj", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Brattleboro Reformer"}, rebuilding of the Ukrainian city of Mariupol, occupied by Moscow's forces.\n\n\"The deputy defence minister of the Russian Federation was sent to a pre-trial detention centre,\" the press service for Russia.\n\nArrests of high-profile government figures are rare, usually the result of political infighting, analysts say.\n\nActivists say the vast sums being poured into the Ukraine offensive has {"uri": "2024-04-333904767", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "12:45:52", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T12:45:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T11:28:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7333333492279053, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/russian-deputy-defence-minister-held-over-bribery-accusations/article_304c37c8-131f-559a-90b0-7962808c5936.html", "title": "Russian deputy defence minister held over bribery accusations", "body": "A Russian deputy defence minister exposed in an investigation by late opposition leader Alexei Navalny's team was remanded in custody Wednesday on suspicion of taking large bribes.\n\nThe arrest of Timur Ivanov, a long-time ally of Defence Minister Sergei Shoigu, is the most dramatic corruption case in Russia in recent years. It comes as spending on the military has ballooned amid its offensive on Ukraine.\n\nIvanov, 48, oversaw construction and procurement for the armed forces, and was linked to Russia's high-profile rebuilding of the Ukrainian city of Mariupol, occupied by Moscow's forces.\n\n\"The deputy defence minister of the Russian Federation was sent to a pre-trial detention centre,\" the press service for Moscow courthouses said in a statement on social media.\n\nHe faces up to 15 years in prison for bribe-taking \"on a particularly large scale\", it added.\n\nIvanov denies the charges, his lawyer told the state-run TASS news agency.\n\nSeveral independent Russian media outlets have alleged that Ivanov and his family acquired vast wealth through kick-backs on contracts he agreed at the ministry.\n\n- Lavish lifestyle -\n\nIn December 2022, Navalny's team said they had obtained thousands of leaked emails from Ivanov's wife, Svetlana Maniovich, that showed a lavish lifestyle well beyond what his official salary could cover.\n\nThey said she had spent hundreds of thousands of euros on luxury cars, jewellery, clothes, parties, and renting premium property and yachts in the south of France.\n\nSome of the transactions were routed through third parties, including defence ministry contractors, they alleged.\n\nThe Kremlin said President Vladimir Putin was in \"constant\" contact with Shoigu but refused to comment directly on Ivanov's arrest.\n\n\"There will be an investigation,\" spokesman Dmitry Peskov said, cautioning against \"speculation\".\n\nIn court on Wednesday, Ivanov, 48, stood in a glass dock for defendants in military uniform.\n\nThe court said investigators believe he was part of a \"criminal conspiracy\" to take a \"bribe on a particularly large scale in the form of property services, during the course of contracting and subcontracting work for the defence ministry.\"\n\nIt did not provide further details.\n\nThe judge sent him to pre-trial detention until at least June 23. He will be held at the notorious Lefortovo jail in Moscow, TASS reported.\n\n- 'Shoigu's deputy' -\n\nCampaigners, including Navalny, have long argued that corruption is endemic in Putin's Russia.\n\nArrests of high-profile government figures are rare, usually the result of political infighting, analysts say.\n\nActivists say the vast sums being poured into the Ukraine offensive has given officials new opportunities to enrich themselves through secretive procurement deals.\n\nRussian military bloggers, who have long criticised Shoigu's handling of the offensive, quickly linked Ivanov to the defence minister on social media.\n\nIn a post criticising Ivanov, Wagner-linked Telegram channel Grey Zone repeatedly referred to him as \"Shoigu's Deputy\".\n\n\"He, like Shoigu, comes from the family clan,\" it said.\n\nFormer Wagner boss Yevgeny Prigozhin had accused Shoigu and other defence ministry officials of corruption and incompetence before his mysterious death last year.\n\nThe defence ministry has not commented on Ivanov's arrest.\n\nJust hours before investigators announced they had arrested Ivanov on Tuesday he had appeared in video footage published by the ministry in which Shoigu addressed top military brass about the state of the Ukraine offensive.\n\nbur/jj\n\nMore from this section\n\nKelly Auto Group Expands with Opening of Kelly Hyundai of {"uri": "8094563701", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-04-24", "time": "09:15:35", "dateTime": "2024-04-24T09:15:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-04-24T09:15:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://meduza.io/en/feature/2024/04/24/shoigu-s-man", "title": "'Shoigu's man' Russian deputy defense minister jailed pending trial in highest-profile corruption case since full-scale war began  --  Meduza", "body": "A day after Russian Deputy Defense Minister Timur Ivanov was arrested for allegedly taking bribes, becoming the highest-ranking official to face felony charges in recent years, a Moscow court has sent him to pre-trial detention for two months.\n\nAccording to investigators, Ivanov took part in a criminal conspiracy in which he accepted \"especially large bribes\" while overseeing Defense Ministry construction and repairs projects. Sergey Borodin, a friend of Ivanov, has also been remanded in custody.\n\nIvanov's arrest was first reported on the evening of April 23. According to Russian state media, he will be held in Moscow's Lefortovo remand prison for the duration of the authorities' preliminary investigation. The Telegram channel 112 said that investigators have begun searching a dacha owned by Ivanov in Dagestan, while the channel VChK-OGPU reported that three other people have been arrested in connection with the case.\n\nKremlin press secretary Dmitry Peskov told journalists on Wednesday evening that Vladimir Putin has been notified of Ivanov's arrest and that Defense Minister Sergey Shoigu was \"informed in advance.\" Ivanov is known to be a longtime ally of Shoigu, having served as his deputy governor in the Moscow region back in 2012.\n\nIvanov has overseen a wide range of construction projects as deputy defense minister, including the Main Cathedral of the Russian Armed Forces, Moscow's Patriot Park theme park, and the reconstruction of occupied Mariupol. In 2019, he was included on Forbes Russia's list of the country's richest security officials.\n\nFollowing Ivanov's arrest, a source told Forbes that Ivanov is \"Shoigu's man\" but that he'd \"had some slip-ups\" and that \"questions had piled up\" around him. The source speculated that his arrest could be part of a \"purge\" of Shoigu's inner circle in preparation for the minister's possible departure from the defense ministry.\n\nIvanov has been the subject of a number of corruption investigations by journalists. In 2022, Team Navalny reported that the deputy minister's family owns multiple expensive properties in the Moscow region. Later that year, they reported that Ivanov's first wife had spent hundreds of thousands of euros on jewelry, clothing, and vacations over the years, with third-party individuals and companies regularly footing the bill.
